title: Learning Church History in a Year Through Primary Sources
description:
I get asked all the time, "how can I start learning about church history?" It's a daunting task given the sheer scale of the topic. 

Over the past few years, I've been honing my answer to this question, and I've spent the last few months creating a resource that outlines a one year reading plan, guiding you through 2,000 years of history using only primary sources. And, as a bonus, all the texts in this guide are available for free online. 

This guide is available for free for all my Patrons, or you can buy the guide separately for $15, here: https://shop.gospelsimplicity.com/products/church-history-in-a-year-a-reading-guide-through-2-000-years

title: Retrieving Pre-Modern Hermeneutics | Dr. Brandon Smith
description:
In this interview I'm joined by Dr. Brandon Smith to discuss his book, Taught by God: Ancient Hermeneutics for the Modern Church. We talk about how Christians have read Scripture over the course of history, what we can learn from the way the Fathers, the Reformers, and others read Scripture. We also talk about what this looks like in a Protestant context. 

Smith earned a B.A. in Biblical Studies from Dallas Baptist University, an M.A. in Theological and Biblical Studies from Criswell College, and a Ph.D. in Theology from Ridley College (Melbourne). He is the author of numerous books, book contributions, and journal articles. His books include The Trinity in the Book of Revelation (IVP Academic, 2022), The Biblical Trinity (Lexham, 2023), and Taught by God (B&H Academic, 2024).

title: This Book Made Me Rethink Hell
description:
Recently, the Christian internet went crazy when Kirk Cameron, evangelical actor, producer, and podcaster, released a video arguing for annihilationism, a view that the souls of unbelievers can be destroyed, rather than being eternally consciously tormented in hell. 

In this video, I offer a step by step account of St. Gregory of Nyssa's view of what happens to us when we die. Less a response to Cameron, and more a patristic deep dive, my goal with this video is to bring another voice to the table in these debates, one that has profoundly challenged my own thinking.

title: How this Church Father Made Me Rethink the Atonement
description:
In the 5th century, St. Cyril of Alexandria arose as one of the foremost defenders of orthodox Christology. Today, he's primarily remembered for his debates against Nestorius, but for St. Cyril, Christology was not just an isolated piece of theology. It was deeply interconnected to soteriology. In other words, having a correct view of who Christ is leads to a correct view of how we're saved. 

Through his insights into Christology, I came across his beautiful vision of what Jesus's famous words, "My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?" mean. That's what we'll be covering in this video, and as you'll see, it has important ramifications for how we understand the atonement.

description:

title: Protestants Need Doctrinal Development, Schaff Can Help
description:
Theology is inextricably tied up with history, and it's all but impossible to claim that doctrines haven't changed over time. 

The question is, are those changes good, bad, or indifferent? And, if change at least can be good in some instances, how do we tell the good from the bad? 

To answer those questions, theologians turn to a concept known as "doctrinal development." St. John Henry Newman, a Catholic, is the figure most commonly associated with this idea, but he is by no means the only person to take up these questions. At the same time that Newman was writing, a Swiss-born, German-educated Reformed minister teaching in America, Philip Schaff, was also writing about this. But he took a different approach. In this video, I outline Schaff's theory of doctrinal development, noting how it compares to Newman's. 

Book in discussion: stpaulcenter.com/obscurityofscripture
My video on Newman's Essay on the Development of Christian Doctrine: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=48IuL9i3KlM

title: Why Some Christian Nationalists Are Defending Slavery
description:
With Christian Nationalism on the rise, there's a new trend: Defending slavery. 

Joshua Haymes, a self-proclaimed Christian Nationalist made headlines for saying that slavery is not inherently evil and that every Christian should be able to defend that. Doug Wilson has likewise caused a stir by saying that slavery wasn't as bad as people think, and that Christians should accept that the Bible teaches that slavery is not inherently immoral in all cases. 

Unsurprisingly, that's caused quite a stir. In this video, I break down why these people are claiming that, what they perceive is at stake, and why Christians can still claim that slavery is, in fact, inherently immoral.

title: What Aquinas and the Fathers Knew About Theology that We Forget
description:
We are finite and God is infinite -- how than can we speak intelligently of God? Is theology a hopeless endeavor? 

Throughout the Christian tradition, theologians have wrestled with this question. On the one hand, Christians believe that God has revealed himself in the person of Jesus Christ. On the other hand, Christians maintain that human words and concepts inevitably fall short when trying to articulate the essence of God. So, where does that leave us? 

In this video, I look at two ways Christians have sought to approach this: apophatic theology and the principle of analogy. 

Apophatic theology is an approach to theology in which we say what God is not, rather than what God is. The principle of analogy, or, "analogical predication," is the idea that we can say what God is like, but not what God is. 

By examining these two approaches, we're led to recognize a need for theological humility while simultaneously not despairing that we can't know anything at all about God.

Dionysius: https://ccel.org/ccel/rolt/dionysius/dionysius.v.html#fna_v-p6.3

title: If You Get this WRONG, Theology Unravels
description:
Back in the 5th century, the church was embroiled in debates over the nature of Christ. Two figures rose to the forefront of the debate: St. Cyril of Alexandria and Nestorius. The animating cause of the debate was whether it's right to call Mary the Mother of God. 

Over the years, the nuances of Nestorius's and Cyril's thoughts have often been lost. Let me be clear: this video is not a historical reconstruction of Nestorius's position. This video is a look at St. Cyril's Christology, and even more so, an examination of what he felt was at stake in getting the incarnation right and why mystery plays such an important role in that. 

In the course of the video, I talk about how the incarnation affects our soteriology, epistemology, and anthropology.

title: The Great Western Schism: Why aren't more people talking about this?
description:
The Great Western Schism is one of the most fascinating and dramatic stories in the history of the church. And yet, many people have never heard of it. This is a story of saints against saints, councils against popes, and rival popes vying for power. For skeptics, it's proof the emperor has no clothes. For committed Catholics, it's a reminder that the church has been through far worse in its past than in its present. For everyone, it's a story worth knowing.

description:

title: The Untold Story of the Catholic Reformation | Dr. James Kelly
description:
In this interview, I'm joined by Dr. James Kelly to discuss the Catholic Reformation. We cover why "Catholic Reformation" is a better name than "Counter Reformation," the Council of Trent, the spread of Catholicism during colonialism, and the impact of the Catholic Reformation on daily life. 

Dr. James Kelly is Associate Professor in the History of Catholicism in the Department of Theology and Religion at Durham University. Read his full bio: https://www.durham.ac.uk/staff/james-kelly3/

description:

This isn't to say they're the best theologians, though they're all quite good. They're just the ones who have shaped my life the most, even though I don't agree with them all. 

In many ways, this video is my theological autobiography. I hope you enjoy it.

title: The Forgotten Idea that Divided the Church
description:
How does God interact with the world? 

It seems like a basic question, but the way theologians have answered it has had massive implications. In fact, in this video, I argue that this is the kind of question that lies at the heart of Reformation divisions--often without people realizing it. 

In this video, I walk through a metaphysical idea known as "participation." It's intimately tied to nominalism, as well as debates about sola fide, the intercession of saints, the role of priests, and so much more. 

Much more could be said about this, and hopefully I will soon. For now, this is a basic introduction. There are a variety of schools of interpretation about these questions, and I'm aware a 10 minute video can only gesture at the complexity. However, I hope this serves as a entry point to these important disucssions.

description:

title: My Reaction to the New Archbishop of Canterbury
description:
For the first time in history, the Archbishop of Canterbury is a woman. What does that mean for Anglicans?

In this video, I try to walk carefully through the theological controversies surrounding this appointment. To do so, I talk about the nature of the church, the requirements for a true eucharist, an Anglican understanding of Apostolic Succession, and finally, whether women can be priests. As part of this, I offer what I think is the strongest argument against women's ordination and the corresponding strongest defense (neither of which are original to me). 

Along the way, I engage with Pope John Paul II, Sean Luke of Anglican Aesthetics, Rowan Williams, and Sarah Coakley, to name a few. 

As I mention in this video, this is not a comprehensive case for women's ordination. Nor is it a video meant to convince non-Anglicans. My chief argument is that, on Anglican principles, this need not be cause for doom and gloom.

title: What Happens When Your Conscience Disagrees with the Church?
description:
In this interview, I'm joined by Dr. Ian Christopher Levy to discuss freedom of conscience in medieval Catholic theology. We pay special attention to how this medieval theology showed up in the trial of Jan Hus, the Great Western Schism, and the condemnation of Martin Luther at the Diet of Worms. 

Dr. Ian Christopher Levy (Ph. D. Marquette University) is Professor of Historical theology at Providence College. He is a leading expert in medieval biblical exegesis, sacraments, and ecclesiology. His latest book, With a Pure Conscience: Christian Liberty before the Reformation, chronicles the development of the medieval conception freedom of conscience with special attention given to how freedom of conscience relates to church authority. 

With a Pure Conscience: https://amzn.to/3IBDTiN
Holy Scripture and the Quest for Authority at the End of the Middle Ages: https://amzn.to/4gLng0U

title: My Honest Concerns About Mariology
description:
True Devotion to Mary is a classic of Catholic Mariology. Multiple popes have commended it, but it has long horrified Protestants. In this video, I try to work through its main arguments, understanding it on its own terms where I can, and offering my honest concerns where I can't. 

As I state in this video, I'm not trying to dunk on Catholicism. This isn't a gotcha, not least of which because this isn't a magisterial text. Instead, it's an attempt to do ecumenical theology, which must be rooted in conviction and charity. Hopefully I struck that balance ok.

title: This Feels Like a Pivotal Moment
description:
A few days ago, I sat down with a heavy heart to talk about the need to not be led by anger, but instead to dare to hope. I filmed it, edited it, and scheduled it for the end of the week.

Then Charlie Kirk was assassinated. 

Suddenly, the video felt both more necessary, but also potentially tone deaf. In the end, I decided to keep the video, but add onto it to address this tragic news.

I didn't know Charlie Kirk, nor would we agree on everything, but I am deeply troubled by rising rates of political violence from all sides in this country. Additionally, I'm worried about how we respond. 

It seems to me that we find ourselves as a church and a culture at a pivotal crossroads. Already, the way of anger has been seen as the most effective way of reaching people for either the gospel or our political ideologies. The thing about that, is anger and violence only seem to breed more of the same. And that really concerns me. 

This video is about those concerns.

Along the way, I ask:

title: Vatican 1: An In-Depth Guide
description:
Vatican 1 represents a pivotal moment in the life of the Catholic Church. It was there that Papal Infallibility was proclaimed as dogma, and the Christian world is still feeling the reverberations of that declaration. 

And yet, even for most well-informed Christians, this is all they know about the council. But the full story reveals much more. Yes, Vatican 1 declared papal infallibility as dogma, but it also had important things to say about faith, reason, and dogma in general. More than that though, understanding the council takes more than reading the documents--you need to peel back the layers and see the story that shaped the council. It's one where vibrant characters worked hard to push competing visions of what the church is and how it should address the problems of the modern world. 

Books mentioned: https://amzn.to/485d28W

title: Protestants Are Losing Online ... Here's Why
description:
Have you ever noticed that the denominational apologetics scene on YouTube is dominated by Catholics? Why is that? 

In this video, I dive into a few reasons why, at least at the level of YouTube apologetics, Protestants are lagging behind Catholics. 

This isn't a video about who's right and who's wrong. It's a video about the reality of the dynamics involved in this space. As I mention in the video, I'm not too fond of the language of winning and losing. I think we're on the same team in the grand scheme of things. But it's true, Catholics are producing more content and to greater effect in this space. That's not to say more people are becoming Catholic than Protestant (the inverse is true), but I'd wager that, among those making their decision based on YouTube apologetics, more people are becoming Catholic than Protestant.

title: How Should Protestants Think About Mary?
description:
Today, August 15, is the Feast of the Blessed Virgin Mary in the Anglican Tradition, the Feast of the Bodily Assumption of Mary in the Roman Catholic Tradition, and the Feast of the Dormition in the Eastern Orthodox Tradition. In light of that, I wanted to take a moment to pause and talk about how Protestants can honor Mary without becoming any less Protestant. 

This is not a video about dogmatics. We can talk about that another day. Today is about seeing Mary not as a theological problem but as an inspiration in faith and an impetus to be drawn back to the wonder of the incarnation.

title: Why C.S. Lewis Didn't Become Catholic (even though everyone thought he would)
description:
CS Lewis is one of the most popular Christian writers of the last 200 years, and he's loved by Christians of all denominations. Both in his own lifetime and well after his death, people have been puzzled by why he didn't become Catholic, despite being good friends with JRR Tolkien and respecting the Catholic Church. 

In this video, I dive into a fairly unknown essay of his that sheds some light on this, as well as a letter from his wife and another of his own letters. Put together, we begin to see why C.S. Lewis chose to be a Protestant.

title: What Happens When Protestants Study Church History? 5 Models
description:
While some Protestants grow up learning about church history, in the American Evangelical world, that's more of an exception, rather than the rule. Because of this, when Protestants first encounter church history, it can often be a rather jarring experience. What's interesting, though, is that people can look at the same data and come to radically different conclusions. 

In this video, I present 5 models of how Protestants engage church history and what they can lead to. Obviously, these are not exhaustive and people's personal decision-making is often quite complex. However, I think this taxonomy is helpful for us to see why people respond the way they do.

title: Should Protestants Join the Mainline?
description:
Recently, @TruthUnites and @redeemed_zoomer had a dialogue on whether Protestants should join the mainline, the Reconquista, and much more. 

These are two men I've enjoyed getting to know through the wild but wonderful world of Christian YouTube, and I consider them both brothers in Christ. 

In this video, I share a few thoughts on their dialogue, though my main focus is given to the question, how should Protestants choose a church? It's not entirely easy. Within that, I provide three further questions to think through:
1. What is Protestantism?
2. What is the Gospel?
3. What's most important?

I hope this provides helpful food for thought for those of you endeavoring to make your way along this path. Wherever you go, I pray you find Christ there.

title: Maximus the Confessor, Universalism, and Mind-Blowing Theology
description:

In this conversation, Dr. Jordan Daniel Wood discusses the intersection of St. Maximus the Confessor's thought and the concept of universalism. He explores how Maximus's understanding of creation as incarnation challenges traditional views of time and the nature of the incarnation itself. Wood argues that the incarnation is not merely a historical event but the very logic of creation, revealing a deeper connection between God and humanity. He emphasizes the importance of scripture and personal experience in shaping Maximus's theological insights, ultimately presenting a vision of a God who desires to be in relationship with creation. In this conversation, JDW explores the implications of viewing creation as an incarnation, addressing concerns about pantheism and secularism. He discusses the ethical responsibilities that arise from this perspective, particularly in relation to how we treat the poor and the environment. The dialogue also delves into the theological implications of animals in heaven, drawing on the thoughts of Maximus. Furthermore, JDW reflects on the historical reception of Maximus's ideas and the dynamic nature of tradition in theology, emphasizing the importance of engaging with both historical and contemporary theological insights.

Check out his book: https://amzn.to/4dpkFI8
Check out his Substack: https://substack.com/@jordandanielwood1

title: Responding to @CapturingChristianity on Sola Scriptura: BTW, Sola Scriptura is True
description:

Recently, Cameron Bertuzzi from the channel @CapturingChristianity made a video giving nine reasons why he thinks Sola Scriptura is false. In this video, I respond to those reasons. In so doing, I continually return to three important questions:

1. What is sola scriptura?
2. What is the purpose of sola scriptura? 
3. What is the nature of sola scriptura?

It is my contention that understanding how to answer these three questions can help Protestants defend sola scriptura much better. 

Now, don't let the red "REBUTTED" thumbnail fool you. This isn't some knock down argument. Rather, it's simply a thoughtful engagement with the arguments that Cameron puts forth, attempting to show how a Protestant might respond. 

My goal isn't to say his arguments are silly or clearly false. Instead, it's to help find the real points of disagreements between Protestants and Catholics, which are often smaller than we'd assume. 

Read my writings:
https://austinsuggs.substack.com/

title: We Need to STOP Talking about Certainty
description:
Both Protestant and Catholic apologists like to throw around the word "certainty" when critiquing the other side. You'll hear, "are you certain there are apostolic traditions outside the Bible?" as well as, ""are you certain about the canon?" 

And, 9/10, the arguments are no good. Nada. Zilch. No bueno. Philosophically and epistemically bankrupt. 

Maybe that's a little harsh. But I think it's time we took a nice hard look at certainty and decide to let it move off into the rear view mirror. 

Or at the very least, we learn to start distinguishing between types of certainty and be very precise with what we mean.

title: Explaining Descartes' Argument for God
description:
You've probably heard of Descartes' famous cogito, I think; therefore, I am. It has to be the most famous sentence in all of philosophy. But it's not his most radical argument in that book. In fact, he makes an even bigger claim along the lines of, "I think; therefore, God exists." 

In this video, I break down that argument, explaining how the idea of God proves the existence of God in Descartes' famous Meditations on First Philosophy.

title: Protestantism Has an Expiration Date
description:
Protestantism often finds itself stuck between two impulses: reform and reconstruction. If we're to take the path of the magisterial reformation, we must choose the former. But this comes with an important catch: Protestantism then is a means, not an end. Therefore, Protestantism has an expiration date. But how would we know when it's time to call it quits on the Reformation? It's a tough question, but I try to tease some of that out in this video.

title: Chasing Novelty Is Ruining Your Spiritual Life
description:
Too often, when we feel stuck in our spiritual lives we assume that what we've been doing just isn't good enough, so we set off in search for new practices that will finally bring us the dynamic spiritual life we've been seeking. 

And it works. For about a week. Maybe a month, if we're lucky, but soon enough we're back out on the road, in search of something new. 

This approach, this ceaseless appetite for novelty, it's killing our spiritual lives. We're asking trees without roots why they don't have fruit and leaving them to wither in the sun. 

This video is a challenge to change that approach.

title: A Beginner's Guide to St. Thomas Aquinas | Dr. Michael Gorman
description:
In this conversation, Dr. Michael Gorman discusses the complexities of St. Thomas Aquinas' metaphysics, his relationship with Aristotle, and the interplay between philosophy and theology. Gorman shares insights on how Aquinas' works have influenced modern thought and the challenges students face when approaching his writings. 

The discussion also delves into the concepts of substance, accidents, actuality, and potentiality in Aquinas' philosophy, providing a comprehensive overview of his metaphysical framework. In this conversation, Michael Gorman discusses the philosophical concepts of actuality and potentiality as articulated by Aquinas, contrasting them with Aristotle's views. He explains how Aquinas radicalizes these ideas, particularly in relation to God's nature as pure act, and explores the implications for understanding causation and the doctrine of transubstantiation. Gorman emphasizes the importance of patience and persistence when engaging with Aquinas' complex ideas, encouraging listeners to appreciate the depth of the ongoing philosophical conversation.

For a more thorough introduction, check out his excellent book, A Contemporary Introduction to Thomistic Metaphysics: https://amzn.to/4ls15Pe

title: The PROBLEM with "No Salvation Outside the Church" - History & Critique
description:
Both the Catholic and Orthodox Churches have traditionally taught that outside the church there is no salvation -- and they've taught this for good reason. You can find this doctrine all over the writings of the Fathers. 

Simultaneously, many of us squirm at this doctrine today. We're not alone in that. And I think we have good reason for this as well. 

So, in this video I present the history of the doctrine, my argument for there being a substantial change in Catholic teaching on the doctrine, and my alternative for how salvation and the church relate.

title: Christianity is the TRUE Philosophy | St. Justin Martyr
description:
How do theology and philosophy relate? It's a question as old as the church with great minds falling on different sides. In this video, I'll be looking at St. Justin Martyr's teaching in his first apology where he lays out a view that the two go together as fulfillment and seed. Philosophy, for Justin, is the seed and Christianity is the true fulfillment of that seed. 

In looking at this, we'll explore Justin's theology of the logos, and how that allowed him to take a liberating approach to truth, one in which he could pursue it wherever it might be found, trusting that all truth leads to Christ, who is the logos, the fulfillment of truth.

title: Become a Saint, Nothing Else Matters
description:
“The only real sadness, the only real failure, the only great tragedy in life, is not to become a saint” - Léon Bloy.
Growing up, I often thought the goal of the Christian life was going to heaven and getting as many other people there too. That's not a bad goal, but it's incomplete - not to mention we can twist our theology into a knot when all God asks us is to save us from him.
As I've gone along in my journey, I've learned to see things differently. The goal of the Christian life is to become a saint.
But what does that mean?
For most, the word saint brings up pictures of cloistered nuns or long-bearded monks living in caves. And let me be clear, it can look like that. But it doesn't always, or even most of the time.
Becoming a saint is about being joined to Jesus and participating in his cosmic redemption. His work of making all things new.
That's not just a religious thing. It's an all of life thing. Jesus is in the business of transforming everything from the ground we walk on to the hearts that beat in our chest. Nothing is too large or too small. The saint is the one that says, "may it happen here. In my life. In my neighborhood. In my plot of land. May Jesus be all in all."

title: What is the Church? Evaluating Different Models
description:
Want to take your study of the Bible and Church History to the next level? Try Logos, the software I use both for personal and academic work. Use the link below to get two free months: https://logos.com/GospelSimplicity

People spend a lot of time arguing about which church is the true church, how it should be run, and many other things. However, we spend relatively little time asking a more basic question: what is the church? 

In this video, I evaluate five conceptions of the church: Institution, Mystical Communion, Sacrament, Herald, and Servant. In so doing, I ask what the model conveys, what binds the members together, who benefits from it, and what is its goal. I also explore strengths and weaknesses before weighing in at the end regarding my preferred model. 

This video is, in large part, a summary of the great work, Models of the Church, by the Catholic theologian Avery Cardinal Dulles.

title: My Thoughts on Sola Scriptura: Responding to Common Objections
description:
Sola Scriptura gets a lot of hate on the internet. If you watch my videos, there's a pretty good chance you disagree with sola scriptura, perhaps quite strongly. 

In this video, I lay out how I define sola scriptura and why I think common objections don't quite land. I cover things like the problem of canonicity, inconsistent definitions of sola scriptura, whether sola scriptura could function in the early church, what the fathers thought about it, and whether it leads to endless divisions. 

My goal in this video isn't to persuade you to adopt sola scriptura. Instead, my goal is to simply show that it might not be as crazy as people seem to think it is.

title: Existentialism, Ecclesial Angst, and the Search for Certainty
description:
If only things were simpler. 

Ever found yourself saying that in your investigation of church history? Me too. In this video, I speak about that dizzying feeling of being on the edge of finding what you're seeking and yet failing to grasp it. Specifically, I talk about how Albert Camus in his philosophy of absurdity has given me language for making sense of this frustrating feeling. 

By breaking down his philosophy along with Soren Kierkegaard and Edmund Husserl's alternatives, I share some paths forward on the ecclesial journey, with special emphasis on the question of whether the church is an object of faith and when we should take a leap.

About Gospel Simplicity:
Gospel Simplicity began as a YouTube channel in a Moody Bible Institute dorm. It was born out of the central conviction that the gospel is really good news, and I wanted to share that with as many people as possible. The channel has grown and changed over time, but that central conviction has never changed. Today, we make content around biblical and theological topics, often interacting with people from across the Christian tradition with the hope of seeking greater unity and introducing people to the beautiful simplicity and transformative power of the gospel, the good news about Jesus.

About the host:
Austin Suggs holds a BA in Theology from Moody Bible Institute and is currently pursuing an MA in Liberal Arts with a focus in Theology and Philosophy from St. John's College, Annapolis. He has served in the local church in a number of ways, including as a full-time staff member,, teacher, church planter, and more. Today, he resides outside of Baltimore with his wife Eliza.

title: Can the Church Fathers and Evangelicalism Mix?
description:
Protestants are showing increasing interest in tradition. People are looking to the early church and saying, "how can we incorporate this theology and spirituality into our modern lives?" 

On the whole, I think this is wonderful. At both the theological and personal level, I've benefited greatly from this movement. However, I think there are also problems lurking within it. As Evangelicals seek tradition, they'll have to decide, how far will we go, and in what sense can we claim the Fathers as our own?

Dr. East's Article in which he notes the lack of the sacraments in Comer's work: https://www.christianitytoday.com/2024/02/john-mark-comer-practicing-way-jesus-apprentice/

title: The Case for Liberal Protestantism | Dr. Steven Nemes
description:
In this video, I'm joined by Dr. Steven Nemes to discuss his case for liberal Protestantism. 

Dr. Nemes spent years wondering if he needed to become Catholic and leave his Protestant upbringing. He ended up rejecting the claims of the Catholic church. However, he did not stop there. He realized that the nature of his disagreements with Roman Catholicism extended beyond the institution of the church centered in Rome. These disagreements went to the core of catholic Christianity as a whole - in other words, the majority of historical Christianity. This has led to his rejection of traditionalism, hierarchy, the Trinity, and the incarnation - all of which he has written on extensively. 

In this video, we discuss what Liberal Protestantism is, my objections to it, whether it can be called Christianity, and Dr. Nemes' views on the future of liberal theology. 

You can find his books, including his debut novel, All the Suns Go Out, at https://stevennemes.com/

title: Protestant Tours a Coptic Orthodox Church
description:
The Coptic Orthodox Church, which is a part of the Oriental Orthodox church, is one of the ancient apostolic churches. Throughout the centuries, it has done a remarkable job of preserving its liturgy and theology. However, until recently, its footprint outside of Egypt has been almost non-existent. Within the last 100 years though, it's made inroads in the West. 

In this video, I'm joined by Fr. David Milad for a tour of his church, St. Barnabas and St. Susanna Coptic Orthodox Church in Baltimore, Maryland. We discuss liturgy, theology, and what the state of the Coptic Orthodox Church in the West is. 

Learn more about his church: https://sbsschurch.org/

title: The Council of Nicaea in 5 Minutes
description:
The Council of Nicaea, the first ecumenical council, was a pivotal moment in the history of the Christian church. For the first time, the emperor was calling Christian bishops together to solve a theological issue. And the issue couldn't have been more important: who was Jesus, really? 

In this short video I unpack what you need to know about Arius, the controversy around Jesus' divinity, and what did (and didn't) happen at the council. 

This was by far the most time and resource intensive video I've ever made. If you'd like to see more, consider supporting the channel using the links below.

title: I Thought I Understood Doctrinal Development... I Didn't
description:
Doctrinal development is basically a cope for realizing doctrines aren't apostolic even though we said they were, right? 

Well, it turns out that, as in most things, famous thinker's ideas aren't well-summarized in memes or comment sections. 

St. John Henry Newman's famous "Essay on the Development of Christian Doctrine" has the poor luck of being a work that everyone thinks they understand without reading it because the thesis is so famous. For years, I put off reading it because it's long, and I thought I basically understood it. This was a mistake. It's one I hope you don't make either. 

In this video, I give an overview of the book and focus on two of Newman's key criteria for determining valid development of doctrine.

title: Protestant Attends a Coptic Orthodox Liturgy
description:
I've spent the last few years doing a deep dive on church history, which has primarily led me to explore Eastern Orthodoxy and Roman Catholicism. But of course, there are other groups within the Ancient Christian Tradition. The Oriental Orthodox are one of those. 

But until recently, I've known very little about Oriental Orthodox Churches, of which the Coptic Orthodox Church is one. 

In this video, I attend Divine Liturgy at St. Barnabas and St. Susanna Coptic Orthodox Church in Baltimore, MD. Then, I share my thoughts on the experience. 

A big thanks to John, for setting this up, and to Fr. David for his hospitality. 

Link to the joint theological statement between EO and OO: https://www.trinityorthodox.ca/documents/Agreed%20Statements-Orthodox-Oriental%20Orthodox%20Dialogue-1989-1990.pdf

title: In Search of a Joyful Protestantism
description:
For this month only, new annual patrons will receive a copy of Gavin's latest book, What It Means to Be Protestant. (Offer applies only to Patrons in the continental United States). 

Support the channel:
Patreon: https://patreon.com/gospelsimplicity
PayPal: https://paypal.me/gospelsimplicity

In this clip, I ask Protestant Apologist Gavin Ortlund, Ph.D., how I can find a joyful Protestant identity. In other words, I've found myself remaining Protestant, less out of a great love for Protestantism, but more so because I haven't been able to assent to certain historical and theological claims of the Catholic and Orthodox churches. Perhaps you find yourself there too. If so, I hope this video is helpful for you. 

Check out the full interview: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P1xpxyzq92g&t=6074s

Check out Gavin's work:
YouTube: https://youtube.com/truthunites
His new book:https://amzn.to/3AlTcYe

title: Accretions: What they are and how they differ from doctrinal development
description:
For this month only, new annual patrons will receive a copy of Gavin's latest book, What It Means to Be Protestant. (Offer applies only to Patrons in the continental United States). 

Support the channel:
Patreon: https://patreon.com/gospelsimplicity
PayPal: https://paypal.me/gospelsimplicity

In this clip, Gavin Ortlund, Ph.D., explains what an accretion is, why they matter, and how they're different from legitimate doctrinal development. If you want to understand Gavin's views, or classic protestant views generally on historical theology, then grasping the idea of accretions is critical. Whether you agree or disagree with his conclusions, I hope you find this video helpful in understanding where he and others are coming from. 

Check out the full interview: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P1xpxyzq92g&t=6074s

Check out Gavin's work:
YouTube: https://youtube.com/truthunites
His new book:https://amzn.to/3AlTcYe

title: The Strongest Case for Protestantism | @TruthUnites
description:
For this month only, new annual patrons will receive a copy of Gavin's latest book, What It Means to Be Protestant. (Offer applies only to Patrons in the continental United States). 

Support the channel:
Patreon: https://patreon.com/gospelsimplicity
PayPal: https://paypal.me/gospelsimplicity

In this conversation, Gavin Ortlund, Ph.D., discusses the meaning of Protestantism as a renewal movement within the church. He emphasizes that Protestantism is not a rejection of other Christian traditions, but a reform and renewal effort based on the authority of Scripture. He also addresses the issue of institutional exclusivism and highlights the Protestant emphasis on the catholicity of the Church. Additionally, he explains his concerns with dogmas around the veneration of icons and the bodily assumption of Mary. The conversation explores the concepts of infallibility and authority within Protestantism, and the importance of abiding in Christ for assurance. The discussion concludes with a reflection on denominational identity and the need for Protestants to rediscover their rich historical roots. 

Check out Gavin's work:
YouTube: https://youtube.com/truthunites
His new book:https://amzn.to/3AlTcYe

title: How Christians can DISAGREE better
description:

title: Why Conversion isn't just "Following the Evidence"
description:
I used to think that all I needed to do was follow the evidence. But now I'm beginning to think that was a bit naive. 

In this video, I explore three ways in which the common advice of "Just follow the evidence" is a bit misleading. In particular, I focus on how value judgments shape how we weigh evidence, and how the problems we're trying to solve impact the conclusions we arrive at.

title: The Bishop of Rome - Can we find a way forward for unity?
description:
Recently, the Vatican's Dicastery for Promoting Christian Unity released a study document titled, "The Bishop of Rome." In it, they discuss the last century of ecumenical dialogue's and the last two millennia of agreement and disagreement on the role of the bishop of Rome. 

In this video, I highlight a few key parts of the new document and share my thoughts on how the divided churches can continue to make progress on this difficult doctrine of the primacy of the pope and what an amenable explanation and exercise of this office might look like.

title: Why are we OBSESSED with Certainty?
Mission: A missing piece of the conversation
description:
When it comes to Protestant dialogue with Catholics and Orthodox online, often the conversation centers on doctrine. And this makes sense since there are real doctrinal differences and doctrine really does matter. But in my own experience and the experiences of others, there's often another factor that goes into the consideration of leaving Evangelicalism: mission. Put simply, Evangelicals see the great work happening in their churches and wonder how they could leave that behind. That's what I explore in this video. 

I also cover the question of whether it would be better if all Protestants became Catholic or Orthodox.

title: Historic Conversions in OPPOSITE Directions
description:
Peter Martyr Vermigli and St. John Henry Newman are two of the most famous Christian converts. The former left Catholicism for Protestantism, and the latter swam the Tiber in the opposite direction. In many ways, they're paradigmatic examples of why people convert to Protestantism or Catholicism. 

Dr. Castaldo's book on conversion: https://davenantinstitute.org/why-do-protestants-convert
His book on Newman and Vermigli: https://amzn.to/48ISXlx

title: Five Protestant Books to Read Before Becoming Catholic/Orthodox (all under 200 pages)
description:
In my time on YouTube, I've seen a lot of Protestants become Catholic or Orthodox. Along those journeys, one of the most common features is the prominence of books. People read the finest theologians from Catholic or Orthodox traditions -- as they should -- and find great wisdom there. However, they often then compare the greats from these traditions with Protestants of much smaller stature. In this video, I want to help remedy that by suggesting five great Protestant books to read while you're on the journey of discerning the true church. Bonus, they're all under 200 pages.

title: Two Approaches to Conversion
description:
Two people with the same information, same questions, and same capacity for reason often come to different conclusions. For our purposes, we often see some Protestants read church history and become Catholic or Orthodox while others don't. Why is that? 

In this video, I share one of the reasons we see this happen, and it all comes down to how we approach conversion and the question of discerning the true church.

title: Theology and Certainty: Reflections on Barth
description:
Barth's opening line of Dogmatics in Outline has been ringing in my ears for weeks, so I wanted to open a dialogue with you all and ask, "Is theology a science, and if so, what implications does that have?"

Depending on how we answer that question, I believe there are significant implications for the questions that divide Protestants and Catholics.

title: Going DEEP on Justification with Dr. Matthew Thomas
description:
This video is sponsored by Logos. For 10% off their incredible resources, visit: https://logos.com/gospelsimplicity https://logos.com/gospelsimplicityorthodox
https://verbum.com/gospelsimplicity

In this video, I'm joined by Dr. Matthew Thomas, a repeat guest on the show and one of the fastest rising scholars in New Testament studies (he'll be embarrassed I said that). 

We discuss his recent article on Justification in the St. Andrew's Encyclopedia of Theology which provides a masterful introduction to one of the most debated Christian doctrines of all time. In the video, we cover some of the key principles over which Protestants, Catholics and Orthodox disagree, such as the location and timing of justification. We also spend lots of time on Luther, nominalism, and why he disagreed with some of the Fathers so vehemently. 

Read the article we discuss: https://www.saet.ac.uk/Christianity/Justification

title: Exploring why Protestants become Catholic (w/ Dr. Chris Castaldo)
description:
This video is sponsored by Logos. For 10% off their incredible resources, visit: https://logos.com/gospelsimplicity https://logos.com/gospelsimplicityorthodox
https://verbum.com/gospelsimplicity

In this video, I'm joined by Dr. Chris Castaldo, a Protestant convert from Roman Catholicism, author, scholar and pastor. We discuss his recent book Why Do Protestants Convert? exploring the phenomenon of Protestants becoming Catholic, diving into the history, psychology, sociology and more. 

Chris Castaldo (PhD, London School of Theology) was raised on Long Island, New York. Since November 2014, he has served as Lead Pastor of New Covenant Church, Naperville. A fellow at the Center for Pastor Theologians, he has authored and contributed to several books and has written articles for publications such as Religion News Service, Christianity Today, Touchstone Journal, Credo Magazine, Themelios, The Gospel Coalition, and First Things.

title: Is Protestantism the Default?
description:
One of the most common responses I get when I talk about why I'm not Catholic or Orthodox is, "well, is Protestantism just the default then?" It's a fair question. But, I don't think people have always thought the objection through all the way. So, in this video, I explore whether Protestantism is the default, whether people should be Protestant until proven otherwise, and whether Protestantism can handle the same criticisms I apply to Catholicism and Orthodoxy.

title: I took my wife to a Catholic Monastery
description:
I've been sitting on this footage for months. When Eliza and I were invited by our friend Fr. Ignacio Gonzalez to spend the weekend at St. Anselm's Abbey, I was torn -- not about going, but over whether to film. I love making videos. I love editing videos and thinking about content creation. But I also knew this was a really unique opportunity. In the end, I chose to only capture a few moments and reflections on my phone so that we could spend the rest of the time unplugged, in prayer, and in conversation with Fr. Ignacio. 

It was a beautiful time, and I hope this video expresses some of that. 

Oh, and we got a private tour of the Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception. So, that was cool. 

I believe we need more monasteries, and if you want to visit and support this monastery, visit: https://stanselms.org/

title: Does Protestantism Lead to Agnosticism?
description:
In my recent video on why I haven't converted to Eastern Orthodoxy or Roman Catholicism, many people remarked that my arguments against these traditions could undermine my faith entirely, if applied consistently. So, in this video I'm addressing the question of whether a Protestant approach to history leads to agnosticism, as well as what the alternative entails. To further illustrate the problem, I consider what these approaches mean for passing the faith down to children.

title: Read LESS to Learn MORE
description:
It's that time of year when people start setting resolutions for the new year, and one of the most common resolutions will be to read more books. For a lot of people, that's a good idea. But for the people who watch this channel, the theology nerds out there, it might actually be counterproductive to learning. 

In this video, I break down how focusing on becoming a better reader and reading better books can help you learn more than if you simply read more books. I also give practical tips on how you can become a better reader, including a glimpse into my notetaking technique as well as how you can find better books (and what makes a book good in the first place).

title: About that papal document
The Radical Perspective on Paul (AKA Paul within Judaism)
description:
This video is sponsored by Monk Manual. For $100 off the Life Atlas course, visit: http://monkmanual.com/GOSPELSIMPLICITY and use the promo code GOSPELSIMPLICITY at checkout. 

In this video, I'm joined by Dr. Matthew Thiessen, author of A Jewish Paul, and Associate Professor of Religious Studies at McMaster University, to discuss a growing movement in Pauline studies: interpreting Paul within Judaism, not as a convert to Christianity. 

In this video, we cover how this perspective came about, how it compares to the New Perspective and Lutheran Perspective, as well as what this means for how Christians should relate to the law today. 

Check out his book: https://bakeracademic.com/p/A-Jewish-Paul-Matthew-Thiessen/492144

title: Paul, Women's Roles, and Artemis of the Ephesians (w/ Dr. Sandra Glahn)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

One of Paul's most perplexing passages is 1 Timothy 2. In this passage, Paul says that women should remain silent in church, and then states that women will be saved through childbearing. This statement has long puzzled interpreters of Paul, but some have found answers in a possible allusion to Artemis of the Ephesians and her fertility cult. 

In this interview, I chat with Dr. Sandra Glahn about her new book, Nobody's Mother, to uncover what Paul meant not only in 1 Timothy 2, but in his teaching about women more broadly. 

Dr. Sandra Glahn (PhD, University of Texas at Dallas) is a multi-published author of both fiction and non-fiction, a journalist, and a speaker who advocates for thinking that transforms, especially on topics relating to art, gender, sexual intimacy in marriage, and first-century backgrounds as they relate to gender. Dr. Glahn’s more than twenty books reveal her interests in bioethics, sexuality, and biblical women.

Dr. Glahn's book: https://amzn.to/3Rft0oc

title: Ulrich Zwingli: The most misunderstood Reformer? (w/ Dr. Bruce Gordon)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Ulrich Zwingli, born January 1, 1484 in Switzerland, would go on to become a leading figure of the Reformation. However, just as quick was his rise to prominence as his fall from grace. After dying in battle, many of his contemporaries distanced themselves from him, and despite being contemporary with Luther, he receives only a small fraction of the attention other Reformers do in current studies of the Reformation. 

Dr. Bruce Gordon, Titus Street Professor of Ecclesiastical History at Yale University, joins me in this episode to discuss the life and legacy of Ulrich Zwingli, which he outlines in more detail in his groundbreaking work God's Armed Prophet. Together, we explore the myriad ways Zwingli has been misunderstood, as well as why he continues to be a figure that defies easy characterization. 

Dr. Bruce Gordon's book: https://amzn.to/49BgI0L

title: Scholasticism, the Glossa Ordinaria, and Medieval Interpretation (w/ Dr. Samuel Klumpenhouwer)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

If you were studying theology in the middle ages, how would you approach Scripture? The Glossa Ordinaria can show us. This medieval text, now translated into English for the first time in the original format, contains myriad notes on the Bible, drawing from the Church Fathers to guide into interpretation. 

In this interview, I'm joined by Dr. Samuel Klumpenhouwer who has taken on the ambitious project of translating the Glossa so that we might all benefit from its riches.

title: Should we even bother reading fiction?
description:
Of all the things we can give our time and attention to, is fiction a worthy recipient? 

In this video, I argue that it is. 

Over the course of this video I lay out three arguments for why reading fiction is a worthwhile endeavor, not just as humans, but as Christians specifically. The arguments are:
1. Reading fiction is a de-centering act that helps us become more just
2. Reading fiction gives us practice seeing from more perspectives
3. Reading fiction is a celebration of the goodness of human talent

title: An Orthodox Priest and Catholic Apologist Talk about the Papacy
description:
In this video, Orthodox priest, Fr. Laurent Cleenewerck, and Catholic Apologist, Erick Ybarra, discuss the papacy. However, this isn't your usual battle of proof texts. Instead, we dive deep into questions of ecclesiology which get to the root of the disagreement between Catholics and Orthodox. Throughout the course of the discussion, Fr. Laurent and Erick tackle questions like:
1. Did Catholics and Orthodox EVER agree on the papacy? 
2. What does Roman primacy mean?
3. What can we learn from the Council of Serdica?
4. When does papal primacy turn into papal supremacy?
5. What's the nature of the Church?

Fr Laurent Cleenewerck is an Orthodox priest serving as rector of St Innocent Orthodox Church in Eureka, California, in the Orthodox Church in America diocese of the West. He is among other things a graduate of the St Sergius Institute in Paris and current teaches theology for the Ukrainian Catholic University and for Euclid University. He is the author of His Broken Body: Understanding and Healing the Schism between the Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox Churches, and the editor of the Eastern/Greek Orthodox New Testament.

You can find Fr. Laurent's book here: https://amzn.to/3sFWBNK

Erick Ybarra is a revert to the Catholic faith from Protestantism and has spent over a decade studying the doctrinal nature of divisions that exist within Christendom particularly between Catholics and Eastern Orthodox, as well as Protestantism. He is the author of the recent book, Melchizedek and the Last Supper. He is a speaker that has appeared on various social media outlets but is known most especially for his contribution as a co-host of YouTube’s Reason and Theology and his own channel, Classical Christian Thought. He is also a blogger at ErickYbarra.org. 

You can find Erick's book at: https://amzn.to/3nYh6mL
You can find Erick online at: https://www.youtube.com/@UCoxp-YBmYzALO_egQ8bN6Bw

description:

title: Touring America's First Cathedral: The Baltimore Basilica
description:
The city of Baltimore is known for many things -- few of them positive -- but many people don't know that it is home to some of the nation's most beautiful churches, including America's first cathedral: The Basilica of the National Shrine of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary. 

In this video, I take you on a private tour of this historic cathedral. During the video, you'll discover the incredible story of this cathedral, which was designed by the same man who designed the US Capitol. 

From the crypt to the sacristy, this cathedral has stories to tell -- stories of faith through the ages and a restoration that brought it back to it's original glory. 

If you'd like to see more videos like this, consider becoming a patron at https://www.patreon.com/gospelsimplicity

Want to give a one-time gift? You can do so at https://www.paypal.me/gospelsimplicity

Like the shirt I'm wearing? You can get your own Gospel Simplicity apparel at https://www.shop.gospelsimplicity.com

Thanks to the kind folks at the Basilica for making this possible. You can learn more at: https://americasfirstcathedral.org/

title: The Formation of the New Testament Canon (w/ Dr. Benjamin Laird)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

There has been no shortage of debate over how the NT canon was formed. Was it an organic process, finished by the mid-second century? Was it an ecclesial process, formalized at 4th century councils? Or was it a conspiracy of power hungry bishops seeking to quell rival Christianities (shoutout to Barth Ehrman)?

In this interview, Dr. Benjamin Laird gives us a deep dive on how the canon came to be. But he goes much deeper than usual conversations. We dive into first century writing practices to shed new light on questions ranging from intended audiences to "original manuscripts." 

Find his book: https://amzn.to/3rP8GQx

title: Reading Scripture according to its TRUE purpose (w/ Dr. Hans Boersma)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

In his book, Pierced by Love: Divine Reading with the Christian Tradition, Dr. Hans Boersma puts forth a seemingly simple argument: we should read Scripture according to its purpose. But, as it turns out, not everyone is in agreement with the purpose of Scripture. Is it a theological textbook, an ancient history, a workbook for life, or perhaps a living encounter with God? 

In this interview, we explore the idea of Scripture as a sacrament, tracing a sacramental reading of Scripture through the medieval period and the ancient practice of Lectio Divina. This is one you won't want to miss. 

Check out Dr. Boersma's book: https://amzn.to/453hErI

title: You need to read this medieval text **Accessible and Practical**
description:
The medieval period is often overlooked. Many people assume that this was an era of obtuse scholasticism, mysticism gone wild, or the Babylonian captivity of the church. Put differently: it's either too hard to understand or not worth reading. 

But this couldn't be further from the truth. The medieval period is home to some of the greatest Christian literature of all time, and in this video, I offer an easy entry point to medieval theology if you're brand new: Spiritual Friendship by St. Aelred of Rievaulx.

While it's far from the most famous or most influential, it's an exceedingly accessible and practical place to start. Read it, and you won't be disappointed. Furthermore, it's something that people from across the Christian tradition can embrace.

title: How to assess doctrines
description:
In a recent Q&A, I was asked how I assess doctrine. In my response, I brought up four ways:
1. Scripture
2. Tradition/History
3. Effect on faith/practice
4. Intuition/Reason

title: Five Principles for Faithful Ecumenism
description:
Depending on whom you ask, ecumenism is either central to the Gospel or heresy. It's divisive, to put it lightly. However, I'm convinced much of this comes down to different understandings of what ecumenism actually is. 

In this video, I lay out four principles to guide faithful ecumenism:
1. Ecumenism doesn't ignore doctrinal distinctiveness but highlights it
2. Ecumenism articulates doctrine, it doesn't develop it. 
3. Ecumenism is bi-directional, proceeding top-down and bottom-up
4. Ecumenism is born of charity and seeks unity
5. Ecumenism is meaningful even outside institutional unification

title: Is AI EVIL?! New Vatican document on AI ethics weighs in
description:
AI is skyrocketing in popularity, but everyone is still figuring out whether it's a ticket to utopia or the beginning of the end. Furthermore, if it's not going away, how do we live with is responsibly as Christians? 

In a new document from the Institute for Technology, Ethics, and Culture - a joint venture between the Vatican's Dicastery for Education and Culture and Santa Clara University's Markkula Center for Applied Ethics -- the Vatican weighs in, giving 7 principles for ethical AI. 

And it's kind of disappointing. 

The document: https://www.scu.edu/institute-for-technology-ethics-and-culture/

title: World's leading scholar shares the life and legacy of Jan Hus (w/Dr. Thomas Fudge)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

On July 6, 1415 Jan Hus was burned at the stake as a heretic. Ever since, his life and teachings have been remembered in opposite ways. To some, he's a visionary reformer and prophetic voice. To others, he's a heretic that led people to ruin. 

In today's video, I'm joined by the world's leading Hus scholar, Dr. Thomas A. Fudge to talk about the life and legacy of Jan Hus. We explore questions like:
- Would Hus believe in sola scriptura?
- Is Hus a proto-Protestant?
- Is Hus a heretic?

To read Dr. Fudge's book: https://amzn.to/46jfIwy

title: The Catholic vision for work, money, and community (w/ Dr. Jacob Imam)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Our relationship with work, money, and community is deeply flawed. At least, that's the hypothesis we're testing in this interview. Specifically, we're exploring what a Christian, or more specifically, Catholic, alternative to our prevailing approaches to work, money, and community would look like. We talk about everything from reviving blue collar work, getting rid of insurance and investments, as well as the need to live in deep community. 

In this episode, I'm joined by Dr. Jacob Imam. Jacob Imam is the Executive Director of New Polity. He holds a doctorate in theology from the University of Oxford. He lives in Steubenville with his wife, Alice, and sons, Blaise and Leo.

title: How the Nicene Creed Expresses the Gospel (w/ Dr. Phillip Cary)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

The Nicene Creed has been the central proclamation of Christianity for nearly 1700 years. In recent times, the Nicene creed, and all creeds, have been labeled relics of a dogmatic past that we should evolve beyond. Whether to be "relevant" or to move outside orthodoxy, many churches have dropped the creed from services. In other parts of the church, the creed lives on, but for many it's repetition is empty. 

Dr. Phillip Cary seeks to revive our hearts and enrich our minds with the Nicene Creed and its expression of the gospel. In this video, we explore the context and content of the Nicene creed. 

Check out Dr. Cary's book: https://amzn.to/3MDt2Tn

title: Money and Salvation (w/ Dr. Andrew Geleris)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

This video is also brought to you by Fox N Sons coffee. For 15% off your oder of $25 or more, use the promo code "Gospel Simplicity" at http://www.foxnsons.com

When pastors/priests start talking about money, people tend to get uncomfortable. As Dr. Geleris notes in his book Money and Salvation, one of the results of this discomfort is that the importance of money often goes unspoken in churches. Of the three pillars of Orthodox spirituality, prayer, fasting, and almsgiving, it's the final that gets the least emphasis. 

In this video, Dr. Andrew Geleris places a spotlight on the importance of generosity, showing that how we use our money is intimately tied to our life in Christ. Whether you're looking for inspiration for a more generous life or a primer on Orthodox views on giving, this is a great video for you.

title: The most DETAILED interview I've done on the papacy (w/ Erick Ybarra)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

This video is also brought to you by Fox N Sons coffee. For 15% off your oder of $25 or more, use the promo code "Gospel Simplicity" at http://www.foxnsons.com

Perhaps no doctrine is more divisive than the papacy. As such, no matter where you find yourself in the Christian tradition, developing a better understanding of the papacy will help you interact with others better and deepen your understanding of the church. 

In this video, I'm joined by Erick Ybarra to discuss his book, The Papacy: Revisiting the Debates between Catholics and Orthodox. The book is a significant achievement and spans centuries of history, presenting some of the challenges to both Catholics and Orthodox (as well as a bit to Protestants) that the papacy poses. We cover topics like:
- Heretical Popes
- Eastern Fathers accepting the papacy
- Pre-Nicaea evidence
- and much more. 

You can find Erick's book at: https://amzn.to/3nYh6mL

title: Theosis as the heart of Orthodox theology (w/ Seraphim Hamilton)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Theosis, or divinization/deification is a core Orthodox doctrine. But what does it really mean? In this video, Seraphim Hamilton breaks down the significance of theosis, showing how it affects doctrines from the veneration of icons and the communion of saints to its impact on the spiritual life. Crucially, he also unpacks how theosis is woven through the narrative of Scripture. He also talks about how theosis differs from Mormon conceptions of deification. And that's not even all of it. In case it's not apparent we covered a lot of ground. 

Subscribe to Seraphim's channel: https://www.youtube.com/kabane

title: An Introduction to the Anglo-Catholic Church (w/ Fr. Wesley Walker)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Is it Catholic? Protestant? Neither? If you're wondering what Anglo-Catholicism is, you're not alone. In this video, I'm joined by Fr. Wesley Walker to bring you all an introduction to Anglo-Catholicism. We discuss the Protestant and Catholic influences of Anglo-Catholicism, the history and devotional practices of the Anglo-Catholic Church, and much more. Wesley describes why he wouldn't necessarily talk a Catholic into being Anglo-Catholic but why he as a non-denominational Protestant found it to be a compelling place to call home.

title: The Best Books from My Theology Degree
description:
There's no escaping it, if you want to become a better theologian, you're going to have to read... a lot. Over the course of my theology degree, I read dozens of required books and excerpts, not to mention even more books for research papers and personal enjoyment. 

In this video, I share with you the most impactful books from my time at Moody Bible Institute. I pull from four categories: General education, Biblical studies, Church history, and Theology. 

Want the full list of every required book from my degree? Go here: https://www.gospelsimplicity.com/blog/theology-books

Need some structure for your reading? Here's a two year reading plan to get through the books from this video. I've arranged it so each season has no more than three books and the complexity grows as you go. Find this here: https://www.gospelsimplicity.com/blog/self-study-theology-degree-reading-plan

Thanks to Christian Ministry EDU for sponsoring this video. To learn more about your ministry educational needs, check out: htttps://www.christianministryedu.org

About Gospel Simplicity:
Gospel Simplicity began as a YouTube channel in a Moody Bible Institute dorm. It was born out of the central conviction that the gospel is really good news, and I wanted to share that with as many people as possible. The channel has grown and changed over time, but that central conviction has never changed. Today, we make content around biblical and theological topics, often interacting with people from across the Christian tradition with the hope of seeking greater unity and introducing people to the beautiful simplicity and transformative power of the gospel, the good news about Jesus.

About the host:
Hey! My name is Austin, and I'm a 23 year old guy who’s passionate about the beautiful simplicity and transformative power of the gospel. I believe that the gospel, the good news about Jesus, is really good news, and I’m out to explore, unpack, and share that good news with as many people as possible. I'm a full blown Bible and Church History nerd that loves getting to dialogue with others about this, learning as much as I can, and then teaching whatever I can. I grew up around Frederick, MD where I eventually ended up working my first job at a church. They made the mistake of letting me try my hand at teaching, and instantly I fell in love. That set me on a path for further education, and I'm currently a student at Moody Bible Institute in Chicago, IL, studying theology. On any given day you can find me with my nose in a book or a guitar in my hands. Want to get to know me more? Follow me and say hi on Instagram at: @austin.suggs

title: How St. Nicholas of Myra became Santa Claus (w/ Dr. Adam C. English)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

St. Nicholas of Myra was born in the 3rd century, in what is now Turkey. He rose to some prominence as a bishop, held a low profile at the Council of Nicaea, and was known locally as a great man. But none of that explains how he became associated around the world with the legendary figure who, with his flying reindeer, brings kids all around the world toys one night per year. In this interview, I'm joined by one of the leading scholars on St. Nicholas, Dr. Adam C. English, to learn more about the true story of St. Nicholas and how he became Santa Claus. 

Thanks to Christian Ministry EDU for sponsoring this video. To learn more about your ministry educational needs, check out: htttps://www.christianministryedu.org

title: Why rituals are essential and what Evangelicals can learn from them
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

In the non-denominational, evangelical setting I grew up in, rituals were things to be avoided. They would deaden your faith and are symbolic of so much of what is wrong with mainline churches, or so I was told. In this video, I explore how my thoughts have completely changed on rituals. More than that, I lay out a framework for understanding the nature and function of rituals as well as give practical advice on how to make the most out of rituals. 

This video arose not only from my journey of investigating the history of the church, but also from teaching a recent series on rituals at my local church. You can find those messages here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N0LF1lr_Tbg

title: Is a theology degree worth it?
description:
I spent three years of my life and thousands of dollars getting a theology degree. And today, my day job has (almost) nothing to do with it. In this video, I explore whether it was "worth it" to get a theology degree, would I do it again, and what questions you should consider before getting one yourself. 

Additionally, I ask whether it's better to get a theology degree online, should you just read the books instead of going to college, and more. 

If you're interested in more videos where I reflect on my own journey, talk about theological education, and more, let me know in the comments down below.

title: What can Christians learn from the Lord of the Rings? (Fr. Andrew Stephen Damick)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

The Lord of the Rings is one of the most popular series (epics?) of all time. With unforgettable characters and an enthralling heroes journey, its popularity is well-deserved. But is it nothing more than guilty pleasure? Should Christians busy themselves with more important things than reading about Hobbits? In this video, I'm joined by Orthodox priest and Tolkien enthusiast, Fr. Andrew Stephen Damick, to talk all things LOTR. We cover everything from his favorite scene to his take on Rings of Power, as well as how the Lord of the Rings can help you read the Bible better. You won't want to miss it.

title: Protestant Reviews Jack Chick's Anti-Catholic Tracts
description:

Ever wonder how caricatures become so popular? Publishing tracts that sell 750 MILLION copies is one way. In this video, I break down some of the arguments that Jack Chick makes in one of his most popular tracts, "Are Roman Catholics Christians?" title: Transubstantiation, Sacrifice, and the Metaphysics of the Eucharist (w/ Cody Warta)
description:
Sponsors: This video is sponsored in part by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

This video is also sponsored by ChristianMinistryEDU.org. Learn more about how you can gain the tools to pursue your faith-inspired future today at http://www.christianministryedu.org

Let's be honest, the presence of Christ in the eucharist can be hard to wrap your mind around. How can the host be the flesh and blood of Christ while looking, tasting, and smelling exactly like it did before the consecration? In this video, I sit down with Ph.D. candidate Cody Warta to talk about his research on the metaphysics of the eucharist and do a deep dive on the intricacies of eucharistic sacrifice. 

The Incarnation of God by Marcus Peter Johnson and John Clark: https://www.amazon.com/Incarnation-God-Foundation-Evangelical-Theology/dp/1433541874/ref=sr_1_1?crid=BPPHJVVBCM6E&keywords=marcus+johnson+incarnation&qid=1667955248&sprefix=incarnation+by+marcus+%2Caps%2C83&sr=8-1

title: 5 Bad Arguments AGAINST Catholicism
description:
Sponsors: This video is sponsored in part by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

This video is also sponsored by ChristianMinistryEDU.org. Learn more about how you can gain the tools to pursue your faith-inspired future today at http://www.christianministryedu.org

Over the past few years, I've been looking into the history of the church, and in doing so, I've been exploring the claims of Catholicism. Before doing my own research, I had all kinds of misconceptions about the Catholic Church, and in making videos about my journey, I've found many people share those misconceptions, resulting in some pretty bad arguments against Catholicism. 

As part of my "5 arguments" series, I'll be covering 5 bad arguments AGAINST Catholicism in this video. I'll also include ways to nuance these arguments to make them better. This video is made in an attempt to elevate the level of dialogue around Protestant-Catholic disagreements so that we all might seek to understand one another better and come closer together.

title: Orthodoxy: the Fulfillment of African American Spirituality? (w/ Fr. Paul Abernathy)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

When people think of Eastern Orthodoxy, they often think of ancient traditions, incense, Greek culture, and so forth. Rarely is "African American Spirituality" on the list. That's why, when I heard of Fr. Paul Abernathy's book, The Prayer of a Broken Heart: An Orthodox Christian Reflection on African American Spirituality, I was instantly intrigued. In this video, Fr. Paul and I discuss everything from the history of African American spirituality to St. Moses the Black to the overlaps between Orthodoxy and African American Spirituality. It's a fascinating conversation, and likely one you haven't heard elsewhere.

Check out his book: https://amzn.to/3JxnkR8
Learn more about Neighborhood Resilience Project: https://neighborhoodresilience.org/

title: My Thoughts on Christian Influencers
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

We live in an age of influencers, and they're not just travel vloggers or make-up artists, they're found in every niche, including Christian content. As Christians, how should we think of the intersection of Christian faith and internet fame? In this video, I share my thoughts on the phenomenon of Christian influencer culture, and how we might approach internet influence in a healthier way. 

This video is a slight departure from my usual interview content. When I first got on YouTube, it started as an outlet to share my thoughts on the topics I cared about most, and I'd love to return to that, while continuing to make the content that Gospel Simplicity has become known for. I'd love to hear your thoughts, both on this type of content as well as how we should think about "influencers."

title: Rediscovering the TRUE Meaning of Sacrifice (w/ Fr. Jeremy Davis)
description:
Sacrifice is a concept that's found all throughout Scripture and the Christian tradition. From animal sacrifice to the death of Christ, sacrifice takes on multiple dimensions throughout the Bible. However, thousands of years removed from animal sacrifices and even the patristic sense of sacrifice, we often struggle to understand the true meaning of sacrifice. In this video, I'm joined by Orthodox monk, Fr. Jeremy Davis to discuss his book, Welcoming Gifts: Sacrifice in the Bible and Christian Life.

description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

The Joint Declaration on the Doctrine of Justification (JDDJ) was a monumental ecumenical achievement in which the Catholic Church and the Lutheran World Federation came to an agreement on key facets of the doctrine of Justification, and declared that, insofar as this statement represents the views of both churches, Reformation era anathemas concerning justification do not apply to those who hold to these beliefs. In this episode, I sit down with Dr. Michael Root, one of the theologians who helped draft the JDDJ (as a Lutheran). We cover everything from the intent of the JDDJ to inside stories about then Cardinal Ratzinger pushing through complex doctrinal standstills while on vacation.

title: What Monks Do and Why We Need Them
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Recently I had the opportunity to spend 24 hours at a Catholic Monastery, living the life of a monk. During that time, Br. Ignacio Gonzalez, one of the monks at the abbey, was kind enough to sit down with me and answer some of the questions I've always wanted to ask a monk such as, "how do you pay for things?" "do you own more than one shirt?" and "what happens if you don't want to be a monk anymore?" In the hour that we had, we covered everything from his vocation story to how often he can wear Hawaiian shirts. I had a wonderful time, and I trust you will too. 

Learn more about St. Anselm's Abbey: https://stanselms.org/

title: An Honest Conversation about Depression, Anxiety, and the Church (w/ Ryan Casey Waller)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

One in five adults experience mental illness. From 1999 to 2017, suicide rates in the US grew by 33%. Suicide is the second leading cause of death for Americans under the age of 35. In 2021, 32.8% of American adults experienced heightened depression (Galea, 2021). To engage in vast understatement, mental health is a massive problem facing people from all backgrounds today. The month of May has been designated Mental Health Awareness month, and in this video, I'm sitting down with lawyer, priest, and licensed psycho-therapist Ryan Casey Waller to discuss mental health. We're talking about what it is, what the church can do, and how the gospel should impact the way we think about mental health. 

If you are experiencing suicidal thoughts or ideation, please reach out to professionals for help. Here is a wonderful crisis line: https://www.crisistextline.org/

Check out Ryan's Book: https://amzn.to/39ZLgim
