title: Protestant Spends a Day in the Life of a Catholic Monk
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Few things grind against the manic pace, consumerism, and commitment wariness of Western culture like the rhythmic, ascetic, and vowed life of monks. In this video, I'm spending a day in the life of a Catholic monk at St. Anselm's Abbey in Washington D.C. As politicians and businessman whirl through the city just outside their doors, the monks live each day much like the last, praying the psalms in community and living out the rule of St. Benedict. During my time, I experienced everything from the 5am wake up call (filmed in real time) to communal meals and the beauty of unhurried walks through nature. It was a throughly moving experience for me, allowing me to be exposed to what I see as perhaps the most beautiful part of the ancient Christian tradition: monasticism. If you've been following my journey, you know that I've been trying to make sense of church history for over a year now, and this has led me not only to interview expert theologians, but also to experience the liturgical rhythms of various traditions. I invite you to join me on the journey in this video, and if you enjoy it, become a part of the community here at Gospel Simplicity.  

Learn more about St. Anselm's Abbey:

title: St. Catherine of Siena - Sixty Second Saints #shorts
description: In this #shorts, we're discussing St. Catherine of Siena, and one key theme from her magnum opus, The Dialogue: self-knowledge. For Catherine, the path to union with God begins with self-knowledge. This self-knowledge must always be "seasoned with knowledge of God" and thus it is two-fold: one the one hand, we see ourselves and our own sinfulness, causing contempt for our sensual passions, and on the other hand, we see God's love for us and his surpassing goodness. Together these produce a profound humility which leads to prayer and a desire to love God with the love that he has given to us. However, God loves us with no expectation of reciprocity, and we can't love God in this same way because we depend on him for existence. What's the answer? God has given us neighbors so that we can give them the love that we owe to God. In so doing, we unite our wills to God and experience true union with God which is the ultimate goal of the Christian life.

title: Thinking about leaving Protestantism? Consider these things first (w/ Matthew E. Ferris)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Every day I receive comments from people telling me that they're leaving Evangelicalism for Catholicism or Orthodoxy. This channel is, at least in one sense, a documentary of my investigation of that question of whether or not I should do the same. However, while there are many Catholic and Orthodox apologists making great content about church history and how it relates to what church people should join today, there are relatively fewer Protestants engaged in these conversations. In this video, I'm joined by Matthew E. Ferris, author Evangelicals Adrift: Supplanting Scripture with Sacramentalism, to discus a few reasons why Protestants might put the breaks on their journeys to Rome or Constantinople. We discuss questions like authority, unity, sola scriptura, and other key issues that divide Protestants from Catholics and Orthodox. 

Check out Matthew's Book: https://amzn.to/3rCKDkL
Check out Matthew's Blog: http://gentlemantheologian.com/

title: How the Church can Lead with Vulnerability and Authenticity (w/ Carl Kuhl)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Authenticity and vulnerability aren't words that people often associate with the church, especially in the age of celebrity pastors and their seemingly inevitable scandals. Evangelicals have especially been the target of critiques regarding inauthenticity. In some ways, perhaps these are well needed critiques. In this video, I'm sitting down with Pastor Carl Kuhl of Mosaic Christian Church to discuss what the Evangelical church can and should be, how it can lead with vulnerability, and help people experience real transformation. In doing so, Carl critiques what he calls the new "Emotional Prosperity" gospel and calls for real vulnerability and honesty in the church. 

Check out Carl's New Book, Blood Stained Pews: https://amzn.to/37oSImn

title: Think You Know what Really Happened at the Cross? Think Again (w/ Dr. Eugenia Constantinou)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Sometimes familiarity can be the enemy of understanding. So it is, often times, with the crucifixion of Jesus. For so many of us, we've grown up hearing the story of Jesus' death on the cross, and we have an answer in our back pocket from Sunday school about why Jesus needed to die on the cross, but beyond that, we may not really understand all that much about what led to Jesus' death, what crucifixion entailed, and perhaps most importantly, the true meaning of the cross. In this video, I'm joined by Orthodox biblical scholar Dr. Eugenia Constantinou to discuss the crucifixion in context. We cover the Jewish and Roman trials, the parallels with the binding of Isaac, the physicality of crucifixion, and ultimately, the meaning of it all. 

Check out Dr. Constantinou's Newest Book, The Crucifixion of the King of Glory: https://amzn.to/3xo0WWu

title: Touring an AMAZING Evangelical Church (Mosaic Christian Church: Part 1)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Over the past year, I've been investigating the depth and breadth of the Christian tradition through interviews and church tour videos with Christians of diverse church backgrounds. However, it wasn't until recently that I even thought of touring an Evangelical church like the one I grew up in. I suppose, I'm just too familiar with them already. Nevertheless, I've seen your comments and heard your requests, and today I'm taking you all on a tour of a church that has a special place in my heart: Mosaic Christian Church. Mosaic Christian Church is a non-denominational church in Elkridge, MD, and their lead pastor Carl Kuhl was kind enough to show me around their new building, talking about how the building is a visual representation of their theology and mission. In this video, we'll be starting out in the lobby, and in future videos we'll be moving through the auditorium, offices, kids areas, and more. 

Learn more about Mosaic: https://www.mosaicchristian.org

title: The History and Beauty of the Syro-Malabar Catholic Church
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

As I've been exploring and investigating Catholicism for a little a year now, one of the most common comments that I receive is "the Catholic Church is more than the Latin Rite. You should visit an Eastern Catholic Church." Recently, I toured a Syro-Malabar Cathedral, a Catholic church with based in India, going all the way back to St Thomas the Apostle. This video is part two of that experience where I sit down with Fr. Joby to discuss the history of the syro-malabar church and what that means for the Catholic church today.

title: Meaning, Happiness, and a Life of Virtue (w/ Fr. Gregory Pine)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

While many are seeking happiness and a life of ease, virtue has seemingly fallen out of style. In this interview, Fr. Gregory Pine talks about the connection between meaning, happiness, and virtue. In doing so, we cover questions such as "how to be more confident" and "how to be more decisive" as well as more theoretical questions, such as the role prudence plays in aligning all the other virtues. Whether you're looking for practical advice on living a life of virtue or you want to know the importance of the overlooked virtue of prudence, this video is for you. And, of course, since this is Fr. Pine, we talk about everything from the gestation period of whales to Homer. So, yeah, there's something for everyone. 

To Get Fr. Pine's New Book on Prudence: https://amzn.to/3JOaI7u

title: The Politicization of Orthodoxy and the War in Ukraine (w/ Dr. Cyril Hovorun)
description:
At the time of filming (March 23rd) the war in Ukraine has waged for nearly a month. Our TV screens and news feeds are filled with horrifying images of senseless violence, leaving many of us wondering, "how could this happen?" Furthermore, I have been seeking answers to the question "what is motivating Putin?" In this video, I sit down with Archimandrite Dr. Cyril Hovorun, a Ukrainian Orthodox Priest and Scholar to discuss the politicization and weaponization of Orthodoxy in Russia. In so doing, Dr. Hovorun shares his vision for the "De-Putinization" of Orthodoxy in Russia: a process of separating theology and ideology, especially the concept of the "Russian World." 

I bring this video with recognition of the severity of the issues at hand. As a Christian, I call for peace, and as an individual with political opinions, I thoroughly side with the people of Ukraine. I welcome discussion and disagreement in the comments. I ask that in all conversations on this topic we remember the human beings, on all sides, losing their lives in this conflict.

title: Why NEITHER Anti-Racism or Color Blindness Work (w/ Dr. George Yancey)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Few topics have created more strife in the church in recent years than views on race, racism, and what should be done to address issues of racism, past and present, in the church. This week, I'm joined by sociologist and author Dr. George Yancey to discuss his new book, Beyond Racial Divisions, which offers a third way to healing racial divisions: mutual accountability. Dr. Yancey offers strident criticisms of two prevailing approaches to dealing with racism: color blindness and anti-racism and shows that what we need is a collaborative, long term solution. No matter your views on the topic, this video is likely to challenge you. If you ask me, that's a good thing. Learning requires growth and challenge. 

Get Dr. Yancey's book: https://amzn.to/3N0wwyM

title: How You Can be WESTERN and Truly Orthodox: Intro to Western Rite Orthodoxy (w/ Fr. Patrick Cardine)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

As I've looked into Orthodoxy over the past year, one thing has consistently plagued my thoughts: I'm simply not Eastern. Therefore, even contemplating becoming Orthodox at any level seemed disingenuous. However, when I shared these thoughts in a video, many of you suggested that I sit down for a conversation with Fr. Patrick Cardine to discuss the Western Rite in Orthodoxy. To be honest, this wasn't something I had much familiarity with at all, but I was deeply intrigued. In this video, Fr. Patrick and I discuss the history and need for the Western Rite. In so doing, we discuss common misunderstandings and caricatures of the West within Orthodoxy, specifically in its apologetic material. 

To Learn More about Fr. Patrick's work: https://www.orthodoxwest.com/

title: Orthodox Priest and Russian Historian Explains the Historical Background to the War in Ukraine
description:
At the time of filming, war in Ukraine continues, and for many of us, our heads are spinning as we try to make sense of this violence. While many news reports have seen this as an isolated whim by an unhinged political leader, Fr. John Strickland, Orthodox priest and Russian Historian, urges us to look at the historical background as we try to make sense of this. Specifically, in order to understand the war in Ukraine, we must understand the religious history of Russia and Ukraine. 

This video covers a very sensitive topic. As Fr. John and I both stress, this isn't a matter for detached academic speculation. Christians are called to respond with love and pray for peace. As with all current events, conclusive interpretations will likely only be seen after time passes. In the meantime, we do our best to understand what is happening and pray for those affected.

title: Baptist-Catholic Dialogue on the Eucharist (w/ Dr. Gavin Ortlund and Dr. Brett Salkeld)
description:
Few issues are of greater importance to theology and the life of the church than the question of the nature of the Lord's Supper/the Eucharist. Is Christ present in the Eucharist? And if so, how? Questions like this have not only divided Protestants and Catholics, but they have divided Protestants from the very beginning of the Reformation. In this video, Dr. Gavin Ortlund and Dr. Brett Salkeld engage in a dialogue on the Eucharist, focusing on questions of Christ's presence, the nature and circumstances of this, and the question of Eucharistic sacrifice. It's a delightful conversation, and I hope you learn something new!

Check out Dr. Ortlund's Channel: @TruthUnites

title: Protestant Tours a Syro-Malabar Catholic Cathedral (Eastern Catholic Church based in India)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

As I've been exploring and investigating Catholicism for a little a year now, one of the most common comments that I receive is "the Catholic Church is more than the Latin Rite. You should visit an Eastern Catholic Church." In today's video, I'm doing just that: touring an Eastern Catholic Church. However, when many think of "Eastern Catholic Churches" they picture churches that hail from the Byzantine tradition, full of icons and the usual marks of Orthodox churches. However, in this video, I'm touring a Syro-Malabar Cathedral, a Catholic church with based in India, going all the way back to St Thomas the Apostle. This video is a living testament to the sheer breadth of the Catholic tradition, and I hope you learn something from it. I know I did! 

Learn More about Mar Thoma Sleeha Cathedral: https://smchicago.org/

title: The History, Theology, and Spirituality of the Coptic Orthodox Church (w/ Fr. Anthony Mourad)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

For many in the West, the church consists of Protestants, Catholics, and a large category of "other." As people learn more, they begin to think of Protestants, Catholics, and Eastern Orthodox as the three main branches of the church. However, even this overlooks a large and ancient segment of the church: the Oriental Orthodox Churches. In this video, I sit down with Fr. Anthony Mourad, a Coptic Orthodox priest to discuss the history, theology, and spirituality of the Coptic Orthodox church. In so doing, we discuss important aspects of the Coptic Orthodox church such as Coptic christology and the Council of Chalcedon, Coptic liturgy, and the spirituality of a church that has endured a great amount of persecution. 

Check out Fr. Mourad's Channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/CopticOrthodoxAnswers

title: Taking My Protestant Fiancee to her First Orthodox Divine Liturgy
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Over the past year and a half, many of you have had a front row seat, watching my journey of exploring the Catholic and Orthodox Churches as I try to make sense of church history and navigate questions surrounding the "true church." However, you don't often get to see another huge part of my considerations as I'm investigating these things: my relationship with Eliza, my fiancee and soon-to-be wife. In today's video, you get to see Eliza's reactions as a Protestant going to her first ever Orthodox Divine Liturgy. In doing so, she compares her thoughts on Orthodoxy vs. Catholicism as well as Orthodoxy vs. Protestantism. We talk about icons, reverence, liturgy, and so much more. What I think you'll really enjoy is getting to hear her perspectives on these things which are often different than my nerdy, theological reflections.

title: The Core Causes of the Catholic/Orthodox Schism (w/ Erick Ybarra)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

The somewhat ironically titled "Great Schism" is one of the great tragedies of the Christian Church, resulting in one of the largest and most long-lasting divisions the Church has ever endured. The mutual excommunications between the bishop of Rome and the bishop of Constantinople in 1054 did not happen overnight. Tensions had grown to a boiling point, and in this video, Erick Ybarra joins me to help walk us through what some of the key reasons behind the great schism were. In doing so, my hope is that it will help you understand some of the deep seated divisions between Catholics and Orthodox, and maybe, just maybe, help heal old wounds. Specifically, we look at four contributing factors to the schism: leavened vs. unleavened bread, the insertion of the filioque, the theology of the filioque, and the jurisdiction of the bishop of Rome. These issues continue to divide Orthodox and Catholics, so if you're like me, trying to sort through these divisions, I think this video will be of great help to you. 

Get Erick's Book on the Lord's Supper: https://amzn.to/3pgJv5l

title: Protestant Tours BEAUTIFUL Catholic Monastery
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

For the past year and a half, I've been investigating the history of the Church, trying to make sense of what the Church is, where it came from, and how we should engage with it in the modern world. This has set me on a collision course with the claims of Catholicism and Orthodoxy. To investigate these claims, I've set out to interview the smartest people I can find and ask them the most pressing questions of church history. However, I've tried to make this investigation more than just an academic pursuit. Instead, I've sought to also get to know the heartbeat of the Catholic and Orthodox church, understanding their liturgical life by visiting some of their churches and attending their liturgies. In this video, I'm exploring a facet of Catholicism that has always interested me academically, but that I've never explored experientially: monasticism. Thanks to the kindness of Prior Peter and the monks of the Monastery of the Holy Cross in Chicago, I was able to to tour this wonderful monastery and ask questions about Benedictine Catholic monasticism from how much of the day is spent in silence to prayer and much more. If you want to know what a monastery looks like and what a day in the life of a monk consists of, this is for you. 

Learn More about the Monastery of the Holy Cross or plan a retreat there: https://www.chicagomonk.org
Check out a video of Solemn Vespers at the Monastery:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IWYvGsPNsrs&t=1s

title: What Vatican II REALLY Teaches... and how the implementation fell short (w/ Fr. Blake Britton)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Few things spark more internet controversy among Catholics than Vatican II. As many seek to be faithful to the tradition of the church, they wonder what to do with Vatican II, this council that seems to be the source of so many problems in the Church today. Whether it's irreverent liturgies or heterodox theology, Vatican II is seen by many to be the birthplace of many ills. However, in this video I'm joined by Fr. Blake Britton as we take a deep dive into the history and texts of the Second Vatican Council. We explore why the council was called., what it teaches, and how the implementation of the council often radically differed from the teachings of the council.

title: Great Books and the Love of Learning: The Medieval Mind of CS Lewis (w/ Dr. Jason Baxter)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

CS Lewis is beloved by Christians from across the spectrum of the Christian tradition for his erudite yet accessible apologetics and his winsome fiction writing. However, most people aren't familiar with a "third Lewis" which he himself saw foundational to his identity: Lewis the Medievalist. A celebrated scholar and Oxford Don, Lewis spent most of his life researching medieval texts and lecturing students on the importance of honing their Latin. In this interview, I'm joined by Dr. Jason Baxter to discuss the Medieval Mind of CS Lewis, and in doing so, we talk about the importance of learning in our fast-paced, soundbite culture. We explore the writers and theologians who most impacted Lewis and discuss how we might imitate his love for learning. 

Get a signed copy of Dr. Baxter's Book: https://www.jasonmbaxter.com

title: The Great Schism and the Decline of the West (w/ Fr. John Strickland)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Today, countless people are heralding the decline of the West, especially in religious circles. However, there seems to be no consensus on the source of this decline. Some point to the Reformation as the beginning of the end. Others look to the Renaissance and beyond. However, Fr. John Strickland takes us back further pointing to the Great Schism (the divide between Catholics and Orthodox) as the source of the West's ills. Specifically, Fr. John demonstrates how the West began to lose its sense of paradise, the in-breaking of the Kingdom of God on Earth.

title: How Medieval Interpreters Saw Mary EVERYWHERE in Scripture (w/ Dr. Rachel Fulton Brown)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

As a Protestant, trained by Protestant Bible and Theology professors, when I come across some medieval interpretations that see Mary in places in the Bible I never would have seen her, sometimes I can be a bit perplexed, to say the least. Furthermore, I grew up being taught that the Middle Ages was a time when we saw that Catholic church "worshipping" Mary like a goddess. Well, in this video we tie these ideas together by talking about Medieval Marian Devotion, and how the Little Office of the Virgin Mary helped Medieval Christians see Mary EVERYWHERE in Scripture. Furthermore, Dr. Brown shares how this is not a late, pagan development, but rather that Marian devotion has ALWAYS been a part of Christian belief and practice. 

Check out her book: https://amzn.to/318PTCs

title: Black Saints and Slave Communities in Early Modern Catholicism (w/ Dr. Erin Rowe)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Continuing in our series, "Saints You Should Know," in this episode I'm joined by Dr. Erin Rowe to talk about the role of black saints in slave communities during early modern global Catholicism based on her recent scholarly monograph on the subject. In this interview, we talk about two key figures specifically: Benedict of Palermo and Antonio da Nato. Additionally, we talk about how to understand the church's role in the slave trade and how to balance understanding context while also retaining moral convictions.

title: Protestant Looks Into Orthodoxy: One Year Later
description:

One year ago, I toured an Orthodox church, and that sent me on a wild journey of looking into church history, trying to make sense of where the church came from so that I might better understand where it is I'm supposed to be. title: Fully Lakota, Fully Catholic: Nicholas Black Elk (w/ Jon M. Sweeney)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

In honor of Native American heritage month, I'm bringing you the first of two interviews on Christianity in Native American communities. This first video is another installment in our series, "Christians You Should Know," and in it I'm joined by Jon Sweeney, author of over 40 books, including a recent book on Nicholas Black Elk. By examining the life of Nicholas Black Elk, we're able to explore questions about the legacy of Christian interaction with Native Americans as well as what contextualization looks like. Bishop Robert Barron has referred to Nicholas Black Elk as an example par excellence of what a catechist should be. In his life, we see someone who is fully Native American and fully Catholic at the same time. Stick around until the end for a discussion on Nicholas Black Elk's cause for canonization in the Catholic Church.  

Buy Jon's book: https://amzn.to/30k1Q7S

title: How Aquinas and Medieval Theologians Read Scripture (w/ Dr. Thomas Ryan)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

In my evangelical hermeneutics classes, little was said about Medieval biblical interpretation besides that it was bad and marked by ungrounded allegories. However, that summary never felt quite adequate, and when I found out that Aquinas himself was not just a systematic theologian but also a biblical exegete, I knew there was more to learn. That desire to learn more about the subject gave rise to this interview with Dr. Thomas Ryan, an expert on Medieval Biblical interpretation and one of the editors of the Bible in Medieval Tradition commentary series. In this interview we discuss how Aquinas and other Medieval theologians approached Scripture to see what we can all learn from this. 

Check out the Bible in Medieval Tradition Series: https://amzn.to/3q9J3XH

title: Fr. Bernhard Lichtenberg - Christians You Should Know (but don't) #shorts
description:
#shorts
The church's failure (both Protestant and Catholic), to do more to help Jews during the Holocaust is well known. Many might have heard of Dietrich Bonhoeffer or St. Maximillian Kolbe as exceptional examples, but far too few of us have heard of the courage of Fr. Bernhard Lichtenberg, a Catholic priest who was arrested by the Nazis for praying for Jews daily and calling on Christians to love their neighbors as themselves. 

This video is part of a larger series of videos dedicated to exposing Christians to those who have gone before us and are shining examples of the Christian faith.

title: The INCREDIBLE Story of Our Lady of Guadalupe
description: In this clip, Dr. Timothy Matovina, an expert on Latino Catholicism, shares the incredibly moving story of Our Lady of Guadalupe, showing why devotion to our Lady of Guadalupe is so influential in Latino Catholicism.

title: The History and Impact of Latino Catholicism in America (w/ Dr. Timothy Matovina)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Inspired by Hispanic Heritage month, I was reflecting on the tremendous impact of the Latino community on American Catholicism. The only problem was that I knew next to nothing about the subject. So, I did what I usually do in such a situation: find the smartest person writing on the subject and ask them lots of questions. On today's show, I am joined by Dr. Timothy Matovina, Professor of Theology at the University of Notre Dame, who has over 150 scholarly publications and specializes in Latino Catholicism. In this interview we discuss everything from questions of assimilation to history, the future of the Catholic Church and much more. Be sure to stick around until the end for a moving discussion of Our Lady of Guadalupe. You won't want to miss it.

title: Protestant Looks Into Catholicism: One Year Later
description:
This video will be released exactly one year after the release of my video touring St. John Cantius, which not only changed the trajectory of my YouTube channel, but led me down a path of investigating the claims of Catholicism. This journey has put me in touch with some of the brightest Catholic apologists of our time, caused me to read some incredible books, and perhaps best of all it has allowed me to forge friendships with some wonderful people. After a year of thinking, praying, and wrestling, I find myself faced with some of the questions I was asking early on, albeit with greater clarity on the arguments from all sides. I'm not at a point of reaching conclusions, but I wanted to share an update with you all as you all have played such a large part in this journey. Thank you all for the love and support every step of the way.

title: Exposing MYTHS of Church History (w/ Dr. Michael Svigel)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

For many Christians, Church history can be a bewildering wild, wild, west of material. Often times, our conception of church history is shaped more by popular caricatures than substantive historical research. In this video, I sit down with Dr. Michael Svigel to discuss common myths of Church History. We talk about the idea of a great apostasy early on, the origins of the Bible, the crusades, the "Dark" Ages, and more. 

Check out Dr.Svigel's book:

title: Grappling with the Highs and Lows of Church History (w/ Dr. John Dickson)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

As Christians, how do we make sense of all the good and the bad of church history? On the one hand, we see Christians promoting the common good, building hospitals, and transforming Roman society. On the other hand, we see far too many stories of power being abused and things being done in the name of Jesus that none of us want to defend. So, what's the answer? Do we hide the bad parts and pretend like they don't exist? Do we run from the church because of the bad parts? In this video, Dr. John Dickson walks us through some of the highs and lows of church history with nuance, care, and a heart for the church through it all. 

Check out Dr. Dickson's Book, Bullies and Saints: 
https://amzn.to/2XYleGn

title: How WOMEN Throughout History Have Interpreted Eve (w/ Dr. Amanda Benckhuysen)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

It's no secret that the field of biblical studies has been historically dominated by men. title: Rediscovering the Ancient Practice of Memento Mori (w/ Sr. Theresa Aletheia Noble)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Sr. Theresa Aletheia Noble is a former atheist turned religious sister who is best known for promoting the ancient practice of memento mori in which Christians reflect on their deaths to live more fully for Jesus in the present. There's something about death that reminds us of our priorities, and in light of the fleeting nature of life, we're able to see what truly matters. The problem is, far too few of us actually take the time to think about death. Instead, we like to pretend like it doesn't exist. In this video, Sr. Theresa gives you practical tips on how to incorporate this ancient practice into your life.

title: The Stunning Life and Theology of Julian of Norwich (w/ Veronica Mary Rolf)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Julian of Norwich is admired by theologians, feminists, historians, and everyone in between. She's a figure that's hard to pin down and whose influence can be seen from bumper stickers to Ph.D. dissertations. In this interview, Veronica Mary Rolf explains how Julian is both the most and least well-known Medieval woman. In doing so, she brings the theology and life of Julian of Norwich alive, revealing her to be much more than her famous saying (which isn't even really her's) "all shall be well." In this interview, we explore several of Julian's mystical revelations which cover topics from the trinity to the motherhood of Jesus. 

Veronica Mary Rolf:

title: An Anabaptist Perspective on Church History (w/ David Bercot)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gos...

In this video I'm joined by David Bercot, an Anabaptist Church Historian, pastor, and writer who seeks to share the teachings, and even more so, the lifestyle, of the Early Church. title: Orthodoxy, The Early Church, and Second Temple Judaism (w/ Fr. Stephen De Young)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

Most Christians I know want to, in some way at least, model their faith off the faith of the Early Church. The problem, we struggle to get clarity on what exactly that means and would look like in real life. Something that exacerbates this problem is that many of us are unfamiliar with Second Temple Judaism; that is, we don't know much about the world from which the Early Church emerged. In this video, I sit down with the Reverend Dr. Stephen De Young to discuss his new book, The Religion of the Apostles, and explore the world of Second Temple Judaism, the Early Church, and why he thinks that Orthodox Christianity represents the fullness of the Christian faith. 

You can buy Fr. Stephen De Young's Book here: https://amzn.to/2WeeWkZ
Two Powers in Heaven: https://amzn.to/3xbOntw

title: This is the HEART of Protestant Theology (w/ Dr. Phillip Cary)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

What is the core of Protestantism? In this video, I'm joined by Dr. Phillip Cary, author of the fantastic book, The Meaning of Protestant Theology: Luther, Augustine, and the Gospel that Gives Us Christ. In it he dives deeply into the theology of Martin Luther, St. Augustine, and their philosophical influences. In doing so, he shows how the heart of Protestant theology, for Luther at least, is union with Christ. Personally, union with Christ is one of my favorite theological topics, so I'm delighted to be sharing this with you.

description:

In this video I'm joined by Orthodox Iconographer, podcaster, and public intellectual, Jonathan Pageau to explore iconography, symbolism, and meaning. title: What do Catholics Believe About Justification? (w/ Jimmy Akin)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

What does the Catholic church teach when it comes to the topic of Justification? If you're familiar with a bit of church history, you know that justification, and specifically the doctrine of justification by faith alone, sola fide, was at the heart of the Reformation. Churches have split, anathemas have been pronounced, and no small amount of ink has been shed on the topic of Justification. Since the Second Vatican Council, Protestants and Catholics have been participating in dialogues to see if perhaps they can come together on this doctrine. Most famously, in 1999 the Joint Declaration on the Doctrine of Justification was signed between the Roman Catholic Church and the Lutheran World Federation. However, despite this progress, Catholics and Protestants remain divided, and many Protestants wonder what it is that Catholics teach about Justification. Do Catholics believe that we're justified by works? Can Catholics agree to the doctrine of justification by faith alone and what does all this talk about "merit" mean? In this interview, we tackle these questions and more as Jimmy Akin carefully guides us through a Catholic understanding of the doctrine of Justification. 

Jimmy Akin is a Senior Apologist at Catholic Answers. You can find his books, podcast, and more by going to http://www.jimmyakin.com

title: What Transubstantiation ACTUALLY Is (w/ Dr. Brett  Salkeld)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

What do Protestants and Catholics have in common when it comes to Transubstantiation? Well, for starters, most of each group tends to not fully understand what it means, even if they think it's really important. In this video, Dr. Brett Salkeld dives into the the true meaning of transubstantiation as well as the history of the doctrine with the hope of showing what problem the doctrine is trying to solve. In doing this, Dr. Salkeld shows that, despite their different formulations, Calvin and Luther were trying to solve the same problem as Aquinas and other Catholic theologians who helped articulate the doctrine of transubstantiation. While holding firmly to Catholic dogma, Dr. Salkeld seeks to help transubstantiation be a source of unity, rather than division for the church moving forward. If you want to know the differences between Catholics and Protestants on the eucharist, or to know what the Catholic church teaches about transubstantiation, this video is for you. 

Buy Dr. Salkeld's Book: https://bakerbookhouse.com/products/41652
Listen to his podcast: https://thinkingfaith.libsyn.com/

title: What Did Paul Mean by "Works of the Law"? (w/ Dr. Matthew J. Thomas)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

What did Paul mean when he talked about "works of the law?" This question has divided interpreters for centuries, specifically in the Protestant discussion of sola fide. When Paul talks about being saved apart from works of the law, does he mean apart from ANY works, or apart from ceremonial works? This question not only caused division in the Reformation, but it has sparked debates between what has become known as the Old and New Perspectives on Paul. While this fight has been primarily exegetical, Dr. Matthew J. Thomas in his landmark work shifts the conversation to ask how did the earliest Christians understand works of the law. His answers are quite revealing, and if you're interested in Pauline studies, patristics, or just want to know what works of the law means, this is for you. 

Buy Dr. Thomas' Book: https://amzn.to/3ihCXAq

description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

If you're like me, when you first heard about the filioque controversy, you might've been a bit perplexed as to how one Latin word could split the church in half. In this interview, I talk with Dr. Ed Siecienski, a leading expert on the history of the filioque to discuss the history of the controversy between Catholics and Orthodox on the procession of the Holy Spirit. Does the Spirit proceed from the Father or the Father AND the Son, and at the end of the day, does this even matter? title: Orthodox Ecclesiology and What that Means for East/West Relations (w/ Fr. Laurent Cleenewerck)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gos...

What is Orthodox Ecclesiology? For outsiders, it may seem that the Orthodox Church is structured the same way as the Catholic Church, just without a pope. However, in this video, Fr. Laurent Cleenewerck, author of His Broken Body, walks us through the Eucharistic Ecclesiology of the Orthodox Church. He contrasts this with the more institutional model of the Catholic Church, as well as exploring what this means for ecumenical work between Catholics and Orthodox. It's a fascinating conversation, and we talk about topics like what it would take for Catholics and Orthodox to reunite and whether or not the Orthodox need a pope for their church structure to work. If your interested in Orthodoxy, ecumenism, or ecclesiology in general, I think you'll really enjoy this.

title: Taking My Protestant Fiancée to a Catholic Mass for the First Time
description:
Through my YouTube channel, I've been going on a deep dive into Catholicism, and that's led Eliza, my fiancée, to ask some questions of her own about church history, Catholicism, and more. Recently I decided to take her to her first mass, and in this video she shares her thoughts on a Catholic mass as a Protestant. In this video we compare a traditional Catholic mass to the Protestant megachurch she's used to as well as the Lutheran church she grew up in. We also talk about how my investigation into Catholicism has impacted her and much more. For those that are curious, we attended mass at St. John Cantius in Chicago, IL. The mass was in the Ordinary Form, celebrated ad orientum. Finally, please give a big thank you to Eliza for stepping outside of her comfort zone, not only to go to mass, but then to share her thoughts on camera. I was super proud of her, and I hope you enjoy it!

title: Learning to Love the Lord's Prayer (w/ Dr. Wesley Hill)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

For many of us, the Lord's Prayer was the first prayer we ever learned. Some people have been praying it every day since they were young. However, sometimes familiarity can lead to boredom. Maybe for you the Lord's Prayer has just become dull. Maybe it's nothing more than mindless repetition. In this video, I talk with Dr. Wesley Hill about what we can learn from the Lord's Prayer, and how we might begin to love the Lord's Prayer again if we've become bored with it. The Lord's Prayer teaches us so much about God, and it's my hope that this video would give you a greater appreciation for the most famous of all Christian prayers.

title: What the Bible ACTUALLY Teaches about Demons (w/ Dr. Michael Heiser)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

When you hear the word demons, you most likely think of red, supernatural figures with horns and pitch forks, or at least, if you do, you're not alone. Here's the thing: nowhere does the Bible describe demons like that. Furthermore, we often talk of demons as fallen angels, but (spoiler alert), you're going to be hard-pressed to find that idea in the Bible as well. The truth is, a lot of what we believe about demons doesn't come from the Bible, and some of it flatly contradicts the Bible. This is what Dr. Michael Heiser and I discuss in this interview. So, what does the Bible teach about demons? Moreover, how should we allow belief in demons to affect our lives? If all this talk of demons sounds crazy to you, don't worry, we talk about that too.

title: An Introduction to Divine Simplicity (w/ Fr. Gregory Pine)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity

What does it mean for God to be simple, and could someone please explain it to me in a simple way? These are questions that have been on my mind, and if you watch my videos, they might be things you're interested in as well. In this video, I talk with Fr. Gregory Pine, a Dominican priest and Ph. D. candidate as well as a frequent guest of both Pints with Aquinas and Godsplaining, about what the Catholic church means when it claims that God is simple and why the dogma of Divine Simplicity matters. I hope you enjoy this video and the ways in which Fr. Pine can take a complex topic and explain it in simple terms. 

Fr. Gregory Pine:

title: An Introduction to the Jesus Prayer (w/ Frederica Mathewes-Green)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity. 

At the heart of the Orthodox spiritual life is the Jesus Prayer. However, despite it's popularization through books like The Way of the Pilgrim, the Jesus Prayer remains unknown to many Christians in the West. In this video, Orthodox convert and writer Frederica Mathewes-Green shares what the Jesus Prayer is, where the Jesus Prayer comes from, and how you can incorporate the Jesus Prayer into your life in such a way that it transforms your relationship with God, leading to the prayer of the heart.

title: Tim Mackie on What it Means for the Bible to be Unified
description:
If you're a fan of Bible Project, you know that they are passionate about the idea that the Bible is a unified story that leads to Jesus. In this clip, I sit down with Tim Mackie, co-founder of Bible Project to ask what does he mean when he refers to the Bible as a unified story that leads to Jesus, and what does Bible Project believe about the nature of the Bible. To answer this question, Tim gives background on how the Bible came together and what it means for us today.

title: Lectio Divina: Prayerful Bible Reading + Kindred Gospel of Luke
description:
Ever feel like you're Bible reading has gotten a little dry or stagnant? Lectio Divina might be just what you need to reignite a passion for Scripture in your daily life. Lectio Divina is an ancient Bible reading practice that focuses on a more prayerful and contemplative approach to Scripture. In this video I walk you through the steps of Lectio Divina and introduce you to a Bible that's designed for this very purpose: the Kindred Gospel of Luke. Kindred Gospels are beautiful Bibles, and they are tailor-made to help you slow down and read more contemplatively. I think you'll love it!

title: Learning to Pray the Ignatian Examen (w/ Fr. Mark Thibodeaux)
description:
This video is sponsored by Faithful Counseling. For 10% off your first month, use the link, http://www.faithfulcounseling.com/gospelsimplicity. 

In this video, we continue our series on prayer by diving into a classic Catholic prayer: the Ignatian Prayer of Examen. It's one thing to investigate Christian traditions on a theological level, but I think it's equally important to look into the spiritual practices of Christian groups. After all, there's a link between how we pray and how we believe: lex orandi, lex credendi. That's why I'm so excited to bring you this video on the prayer of Examen. This is a super accessible, ancient prayer that will help you be more mindful and grow in your relationship with God. Prayer can be boring, confusing, intimidating, etc. It's my goal that this video would enrich your prayer life, helping you have more meaningful time with God through prayer.

title: What the Bible is and ISN'T with Tim Mackie (Co-founder of Bible Project)
description:

In this video, Dr. Tim Mackie and I explore the question of what is the Bible, what isn't the Bible, where did the Bible come from, and how should we read the Bible? title: An Introduction to Theosis (w/ Jay Dyer)
description:
Hold up, did someone say we become GOD?? If you're like me, the first time you heard this, you were a bit concerned. As an evangelical, the concept of theosis can seem more than a bit foreign. In this video with Orthodox apologist Jay Dyer, we talk about what theosis is (and isn't) and in doing so we explore differences between Eastern and Western approaches to theology. The conversation includes discussion of the essence-energies distinction, monasticism, ways in which Protestants and Orthodox are similar (and different) and much more. I hope you enjoy it!

title: Don't Just Read the Bible, PRAY the Bible (w/ Dr. Don Whitney)
description:
You know prayer is a good thing. You wish you prayed more, and you wish your prayer life was deeper and more meaningful, but you're struggling. Been there? There now? Yup. Most of us have. In this video, Dr. Don Whitney shares insights from years of teaching biblical spirituality about how you can have a more meaningful prayer life through praying the Bible. You read that right. Reading the Bible is great, but have you ever prayed the Bible? After seeing this transform his own prayer life and the lives of countless students at seminary, Dr. Don Whitney decided it was time to write a book on this spiritual discipline to share it with the world. In this interview, we discuss how you can have a deeper and more meaningful prayer life through praying the Bible. You'll find practical tips to get more out of your prayer life as well as how to start praying the Bible. At the end, Dr. Whitney challenges you to try this for just seven minutes. I hope you will. It just might change your life.

title: Defining and DEFENDING Sola Scriptura (w/ Dr. Kevin Vanhoozer)
description:
At the heart of the Protestant Reformation is the conviction that Scripture alone is the infallible source for the Christian faith. Perhaps no doctrine is more fundamental to the divide between Protestants and Catholics/Orthodox than sola scriptura. No small amount of ink has been used, not to mention the blood shed, in the debate over this Protestant principle. In this episode, I'm joined by prolific Evangelical scholar Dr. Kevin Vanhoozer who is well known for his influential works on hermeneutics and Scripture. We talk about his book, Biblical Authority After Babel, and ask questions like, "what does it mean for the Bible to have authority?" and "what did the Reformers mean by sola scriptura?" We sought to clarify misunderstandings, and of particular interest, Dr. Vanhoozer responds to some of the most common objections to sola scriptura. It was an incredibly enjoyable conversation, and I hope you enjoy it. 

Dr. Vanhoozer:
Biblical Authority After Babel: https://amzn.to/3dHLB94
A Reforming Catholic Confession: https://reformingcatholicconfession.com/

title: Why the Essence-Energies Distinction is CRUCIAL to Orthodox Theology (w/ Dr. David Bradshaw)
description:
The first time I heard about the debate between Absolute Divine Simplicity and the Essence-Energies distinction, I must confess, it all seemed a bit like something that only theologians with WAY too much time on their hands debate. I figured I'd leave the philosophical theology to the scholastics and be on my merry way. However, the more I learned, the more I thought I should at least have a cursory understanding of the issue. Then I sat down with Dr. Bradshaw. In this interview, he showed just how important the Essence-Energies distinction is, and how this affects a whole host of other doctrines. In this video he demonstrates how our view of divine simplicity can effect how we view salvation, how we view the glory of God, and much more. I was blown away, and I hope you enjoy it as much as I did. 

Check out Dr. Bradshaw's work:
Aristotle East and West: https://amzn.to/3qsV5c9

title: Are Married Priests the FUTURE of the Catholic Church?
description:
Priestly celibacy is a hotly debated discipline of the Catholic Church (in the Roman Rite, that is). For centuries now the Catholic Church has had a celibate priesthood, yet many today are calling for reform. Some cite scandals as need for reform, while others point to the history of married priests in the early church or the existence of married priests in Eastern rites. In this clip, Fr. Dwight Longenecker, a married Catholic priest, shares his thoughts on whether or not there will be more married Catholic priests in the future. 

Watch the full interview: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kEIBhea0aig

title: The Crucifixion of Jesus in the Gospel of John
description:
Hey everyone! Welcome or welcome back to Life in the Word, the weekly Bible study here at Gospel Simplicity. This week we're diving into John 19 and looking at the crucifixion of Jesus. This is one of those stories that is so easy to become accustomed to and forget just how crazy it is. In this video I invite you to pause and reflect on what is being taught here with the hope that this story will impact you in new ways. Additionally, as we go I point out some Old Testament connections as well as an excursus into the question of what is going on with Jesus' words "behold your mother"? I hope you all enjoy it!

title: INTENSE Discussion on the Papacy (Cordial Catholic x Gospel Simplicity Crossover)
description:
Do Catholic arguments for the papacy hold up under scrutiny? In this passionate yet cordial dialogue between Dr. Gavin Ortlund and Joe Heschmeyer, the arguments for the papacy are examined in detail, including was there was a bishop in Rome in the first century? Is apostolic succession valid? What evidence is there for a three-fold office in the church? Was Peter head of the apostles? And so much more. These two were able to go back and forth, delving into Scripture, the Church Fathers, and the modern definitions of papal infallibility and universal jurisdiction.

title: Talking with a MARRIED Catholic Priest (w/ Fr. Dwight Longenecker)
description:
For many people, "married Catholic priest" is going to sound like a bit of an oxymoron. After all, don't Catholic priests have to take a vow of celibacy? In this video, I talk with Fr. Dwight Longenecker, a former Anglican who converted to Roman Catholicism and was ordained into the Roman Catholic priesthood, all while being a husband and father. In this video we explore why the Catholic church allows some married priests, whether the Catholic church will ever reverse their discipline of celibate priesthood, and what it's like to be a married priest. We had a great time, and I hope you enjoy this. I'd love to know in the comments, should the Catholic church allow more married priests, or should priests have to be celibate? 

Learn more about Fr. Dwight: https://dwightlongenecker.com/

title: An Evangelical Theology Professor's Thoughts on Catholicism (w/ Dr. Gregg R. Allison)
description:
It's been 500 years since the Reformation. Is it time to bury the hatchet? In this interview, Dr. Gregg R. Allison of SBTS discusses what still divides Catholics and Protestants 500 years after the Reformation. What are the core issues that Protestants and Catholics disagree about? Rather than taking an atomistic approach, Dr. Allison offers insights into key dynamics that fundamentally divide Catholics and Protestants like the Grace/Nature interdependence and the Christ/Church interconnection. It's a fascinating conversation, and in it Dr. Allison also shares his thoughts on why so many high profile Evangelicals have become Catholic.

title: Protestant Talks to Catholic Experts on Mary (w/ William Albrecht and Fr. Christiaan Kappes)
description:
When it comes to issues that divide Protestants and Catholics, Mariology is a big one. To Catholics, it seems Protestants are disrespecting the Mother of God, and to Protestants, it seems like Catholics might be nearing the edge, if not going over the edge, of idolatry. Because of this tense dynamic, honest, open conversations between Catholics and Protestants on Mary can be hard to come by. In this episode, I talk with William Albrecht and Fr. Christiaan Kappes about Mary. In this conversation, we focus on what the Bible has to say about Mary. Often times, conversations on Mary center around tradition, and while that's a worthwhile conversation, if Protestants and Catholics want to find common ground on Mary, it's essential that we look to the Bible and see what Scripture teaches about Mary. Is it enough to merit the Marian dogmas? Are the Marian dogmas Biblical or are they all blown way out of proportion? After all, what does the Bible even say about Mary? These are all questions that we tackle head on in this conversation. 

Buy their book: https://amzn.to/3bTWxje
William's Website: https://www.patristicpillars.com
Reason and Theology YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9Z-xXb0tzX2FSCSDEnNJ8w
Study with Fr. Kappes: https://www.bcs.edu/

title: How Do Orthodox Determine What's an Ecumenical Council? (W/ Fr. Peter Heers)
description:
It's no secret that Ecumenical Councils are a big deal for Orthodox Christians. However, what's less clear is how you can determine what is actually an Ecumenical Council. In my investigation of Orthodoxy, I've struggled to find a clear answer on objective criteria for determining the validity of an ecumenical council, so I was very excited to sit down with Fr. Peter Heers to ask this very question. If you're curious about what an ecumenical council is, how we know what's an ecumenical council, or the role of ecumenical councils in orthodoxy, this is the video for you. 

Keep up with Fr. Peter Heers:

title: A DEEP DIVE into Orthodox Theology (w/ Fr. Peter Heers)
description:
In this interview, Fr. Peter Heers shares his insights into the foundations of Eastern Orthodoxy. We talked about pressing issues like the role of Scripture in the Orthodox Church, what is tradition, why are councils so important, and how do we determine what makes an ecumenical council. If you're interested in Eastern Orthodoxy, this video will let you go deep into what they believe and why they believe it, getting to the core of Orthodox theology. This is my most comprehensive video on Orthodoxy to date, and I hope it helps you better understand Eastern Orthodoxy.

title: Does Church History Lead to Catholicism? (Joe Heschmeyer & Dr. Gavin Ortlund)
description:

title: KINDRED Gospel of Mark Review - A Modern Beautiful Bible
description:
The Bible is a book unlike any other, so why do we often print it in such mundane ways? I'm so excited to be reviewing the KINDRED Gospel of Mark today, an absolutely beautiful Bible. Whether you're looking for a coffee table book, approaching the Bible for the first time, or you won't to slow down and change your approach to Bible reading, the KINDRED Gospel of Mark is a fantastic option. KINDRED is a Catholic ministry, and they use the reliable NABRE translation for this wonderful Catholic Bible.  Be sure to check them out at http://www.kindredapostle.com and use the promo cold GOSPEL10 for 10% off your order.

title: Let Not Your Hearts Be Troubled // John 14 Bible Study
description:
In this chapter we find Jesus saying, "let not your hearts be troubled." Right now you might be thinking, "easier said than done." Fair enough. In this video we unpack the message of John 14 and its implications for our everyday lives. We dive deep into the theology that's implicit here including the beautiful truths of homoousias and perichoresis and show how life changing these seemingly esoteric theological truths are.

title: What is the Catholic Magisterium and is it Biblical? (w/ Michael Lofton)
description:
As an outsider looking in, the magisterium is one of the most distinctive features of Catholicism. In this video, I talk with Michael Lofton of Reason and Theology about the Catholic magisterium, what it is, and how it works. We discuss layers of authority within the magisterium, important distinctions about magisterial authority, and perhaps most importantly, Michael Lofton presents biblical and historical arguments for the Catholic magisterium. 

Follow Michael: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9Z-xXb0tzX2FSCSDEnNJ8w

title: An Introduction to Anglicanism (w/ Fr. Thomas McKenzie)
description:
They look like Catholics, their doctrine seems Protestant... what's the deal with Anglicans? In this episode, Fr. Thomas McKenzie, author of The Anglican Way shares what Anglicanism is all about, where it comes from, and why he sees it as the best way of following Jesus. It's a lively discussion jumping from Reformation history to church structure, but what I love most is that Fr. Thomas kept bringing it back to the centrality of the gospel. Whether you're considering becoming Anglican or just want to learn more, I think you'll really enjoy this interview. 

Fr. Thomas McKenzie:

title: Catholic Apologetics, Aquinas, and Following Jesus as a Catholic (w/ Matt Fradd)
description:
When I first started looking into Catholicism, Pints with Aquinas was one of the first resources I came across, and it was through Matt Fradd's work that I was introduced to the world of Catholic Apologetics. Because of the huge role that his work has played on my journey, I was thrilled to get to interview him. In this video we talk about his testimony, how he started Pints with Aquinas, and much more. Matt explains why he thinks so many people are converting to Catholicism, gives sage advice on navigating YouTube growth, and speaks out against the issue of pornography. It's a wide-ranging interview, and I hope you enjoy it!

Learn More about Matt and his work:

description:

title: Is the Papacy an Asset or Liability to the Catholic Church?
description:
Some say that having a pope gives the Catholic Church a firm foundation. Others would say it makes the church into a house of cards. If the pope is said to be infallible and then infallibly declares something that's false or heretical, is the validity of the entire Catholic Church in danger? In this clip, Trent Horn and I discuss this very issue. 

To see the full interview: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JqLrTD3Q15Y

title: Loving People You Disagree with like Jesus (w/ Justin Khoe)
description:
Jesus was known as a "friend of sinners," and he was constantly reaching out and loving the outsiders. While Christians may know we're called to do the same, we don't always follow through on this well. In this episode, I'm joined by Justin Khoe, a Christian YouTuber who is known for making videos with people from all walks of life. He frequently hosts explicit discussions around hot button issues including abortion, homosexuality, atheism, and much more. He does so with great charity, and I was so excited to chat with him about how we as Christians can love across the lines and engage with people who are different than them.

title: Why is Retaining Tradition so Important for Orthodox Christians? (w/ Fr. John Baker)
description:
"Tradition" is an interesting thing. For some, it conjures up warm feelings of retaining the best of the past, and for others it's a bit of a dirty word representing things that need to be left in the past. Of course, many fall somewhere in between. This tension around the word "tradition" is perhaps nowhere more pronounced than in Christianity. Some, like the Orthodox, have a very high value for tradition, while others, like the churches I grew up in, think it's nothing but stagnation and gets in the way of a personal relationship with Jesus. In my own life, I've been on a bit of a journey learning about the Christian tradition and trying to understand how I ought to relate to it. In this video, Fr. John Baker of Christ the Savior Orthodox Church shares an Orthodox perspective on the importance of tradition. 

Full video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bw45OChdnJ4&t=2s

title: Jesus: The Door, The Good Shepherd, and One with the Father
description: Hey everyone! It's great to be back with our Life in the Word series, and this week we're exploring the wonderful chapter of John 10. In it we find two famous "I am" statements. The first is "I am the door" which relates to the idea that Jesus is the only way to the Father and his eternal life. The second is "I am the good shepherd" which is one of the most famous lines of the gospel, and we unpack and explore what all that means. Finally we examine the immense significance of the statement, "I and the Father are one." Hope you enjoy!

title: Historical and Biblical Arguments for the Papacy (w/ Trent Horn)
description:
in today's episode I interview Trent Horn on the crucial topic of the papacy. Perhaps no issue divides Christians more than the papacy. I've said in the past that if you can convince me of the papacy, I'll be forced to become Catholic. In this video we discuss whether the papacy is a solid foundation for the Catholic church or simply creates a house of cards. In addition, Trent provides biblical and historical arguments for the papacy, walking through questions like "was Peter the first pope?" "is there early evidence for papal infallibility?" and much more. At the end of the episode we go through some questions that you all submitted. I hope you enjoy it!

title: Luther, the Reformation, and the Solas (w/ Dr. Jordan B. Cooper)
description:
Was the Reformation justified or did Luther make a big mistake? In this episode with Dr. Jordan B. Cooper, a Lutheran pastor and scholar, we discuss the history of the Reformation, the differences between the reformers, as well as the famous "solas" and why they matter. What do we lose if we deny sola scriptura, sola gratia, or sola fide? Dr. Cooper gives a historical defense of Protestantism and the Protestant reformers as well as his reasons for why he's a Lutheran and despite all the ensuing schism, he believes the Reformation is a net positive. I had so much fun chatting with him and learning from his great insight.

title: Fr  Josiah Trenham on Eastern Orthodox Theology, Catholicism, and the Reformation
description:
Want to learn more about Eastern Orthodoxy? In this video Fr. Josiah Trenham shares his story of converting to the Orthodox Church including why he thinks Protestantism and Catholicism fall short of the fullness of the faith. Additionally, Fr. Josiah shares an Orthodox perspective on Scripture, Tradition, Salvation, and much more. Fr. Josiah talks about the "achilles heal" of Protestantism, the gap between official Catholic teaching and everyday practice, as well as the problems of papal infallibility as well as the Filioque. Of particular interest for Catholics and Orthodox alike might be his discussion of what it would take for the Orthodox and Catholic churches to unite. For Protestants, of particular interest might be Fr. Josiah's appraisal of the Reformation, its pros and cons, and what he calls "the heresy of Sola Scriptura."

title: Rivers of Living Water and a Plot to Kill Jesus // John 7
description:
It's so good to be back for Life in the Word! This week we're going through John 7 and looking at the building tension between Jesus and the Jewish leaders. In this chapter we find Jesus at the Feast of Booths, and if you're not sure what that means, no worries, we unpack it in this video. At this incredibly populated festival Jesus begins to teach in the temple, and he does so with unexpected authority. Then, at the climax of the festival, he begins to talk about how anyone who believes in him will have rivers of living water springing forth from him. It's a fascinating chapter, and I think there's a whole lot here to chew on.

title: Protestant Tours STUNNING Catholic Church (Cantius Part 1)
description:
This might be one of the coolest things I've done. In today's video, we're touring St. John Cantius Catholic Church in Chicago, IL. It's an absolutely beautiful church, and Fr. Joshua Caswell shares with us the history of the church as well as the deep meaning imbedded in the design. I learned so much throughout this tour, and whether you're Catholic or not, I think you'll love seeing this incredible church and hearing Fr. Joshua's infectious love for Cantius. If you love architecture, churches, theology, or history, you'll devour this video. From relics of martyrs to icons with versace necklaces, Cantius has it all. This truly is one of the most beautiful Catholic churches in America. The best part is, everything has intention. The theology of the church is engraved in the floor... literally. You'll just have to see. Get ready to fall in love with St. John Cantius in Chicago, IL and learn more than you ever thought there was to know about the inside of a Catholic Church.

title: Does John 6 Teach that Jesus is Really Present in the Eucharist?
description:
One of the most significant passages that separates Christians is John 6. Catholics and Protestants have been fighting over it for years, and interpretations of the Lord's Supper are what initially split the Protestant Reformers apart. For many, John 6 is crystal clear: we must eat the flesh and drink the blood of Jesus. The way we do this is through communion. Thus, we have the doctrines of Real Presence and Transubstantiation. However, many Protestants, following in the footsteps of Swiss Reformer Ulrich Zwingli have claimed that Jesus the bread and wine in communion are mere symbols and that Jesus is speaking metaphorically when he says that we must eat his flesh and drink his blood. This is a long lasting debate that isn't likely to end soon. However, in this video I do my best to parse through the teachings of John 6 and see what the implications are for our doctrine of the Lord's Supper. This is much longer than usual, but I hope you'll find it helpful. If you want to skip around, use the timestamps below.

04:43 - Jesus Feeds 5,000
11:41 - Jesus Walks on Water

This is the secret sauce. Well, something like that. In this video I'm going to take you through step by step, showing you how I study the Bible. You'll see the resources I use most frequently, how I order information, my process, and much more. This is the inside scoop on how I make my Life in the Word videos. By the end, you'll be equipped to make better observations, understand the historical cultural context, gain theological insight from scholars, find patristic sources, and even arrange a Bible study for others. My goal is that you would walk away from this not just knowing how I do it but learning how you can do it for yourself.

title: What Can the Catholic Church Be Wrong About?
description:
Recently I had the privilege of appearing on the Cordial Catholic podcast hosted by K. Albert Little, and he was kind enough to answer some of my questions about Catholicism. One thing that I was altogether unclear on, and I think some of my fellow Protestants might share this question, is, "what can the Catholic Church Be Wrong About?" So often debates flare over papal infallibility and the authority of Tradition and the Magisterium, but I wanted to know not only what the Catholic Church claims they know infallibly, but also, what are the limitations on this? Is anything the Pope says automatically true? What does the authority of the Catholic Church look like practically? Hopefully this will help answer some of those questions for you. I know it helped me.

title: The Authority of Scripture as Historically Understood by Protestants
description:
What makes the Bible authoritative? This question, and others like it, often come up in Protestant vs. Catholic debates. On the one hand, it would seem that the church, in compiling the canon, has authority over the Bible. This is repeated often by Catholic Apologists, and many Protestants struggle to answer this question. However, for Protestants, the Bible is intrinsically authoritative because of its nature as theopneustos, or, "inspired." So, who's right about the Bible, Catholics or Protestants?

In this video, I give a 4 point overview of John Calvin's case for the authority of the Bible as intrinsic, rather than conferred by the Church. The reason for pulling from Calvin is that many Protestants have lost their historic moorings, and Calvin is really the headwater from which Protestant theology flows. Whether Catholic or Protestant, you might not agree with this case, but my goal is that by the end of the video you would have a better understanding of the historic Protestant case for the authority of the Bible. 

The argument can be laid out as follows:
1) Scripture is inherently authoritative by nature of its status as inspired by God. 
2) Scripture is self-attesting to its authority, given the work of the Holy Spirit. 
3) Any external criteria for authority placed upon the Bible diminishes the Bible's authority. 
4) The Church does not give the Bible authority but merely recognizes the authority of the Bible. 

References:
Institutes of the Christian Religion by John Calvin

title: Jesus Turns Water Into Wine and Clears the Temple
description:
Welcome back to Life in the Word, and this week we're exploring John 2, where we find Jesus performing the greatest party trick of all time then crashing a party rather dramatically. Of course, by these events I'm referring to Jesus turning water into wine and clearing the temple. In this video we dive into the first century background of Galilee and Jewish Weddings, as well as the symbolic significance of Jesus' first miracle and his clearing of the temple. In all of these, we seek to discover how John is using these events to support his thesis that Jesus is the Christ the Son of God, and that we can have life in his name. I hope this video helps you learn what John 2 is saying, what it means for your life, and how you can study the Bible for yourself.

title: Virtue Signaling, Cancel Culture, and Self Worth
description:
Have you noticed that people are constantly trying to show that they're a good person, seeking to be justified by themselves and others? Today we live in an age where we're constantly seeking validation, and in this video we explore what that craving says about us. At the heart of virtue signaling and cancel culture we find the dark truth that when we are not justified by God, we find ourselves trying to find justification in others. It so often leaves us unsure, and wanting more. We tear down others and prop up ourselves so that we can salvage some self-worth, but soon it comes crashing down. 

Through looking at the teaching of Jesus in the Sermon on the Mount and in Calvin's conceptions of sensus divinitatus and semen religionis, we talk about the importance of seeking justification only in Christ.

title: Introduction to the Book of John and the Deity of Christ
description:
It's an exciting day for Life in the Word! Today we are starting a new book, and it is by far our longest that we've explored to date: the Gospel according to John. The Gospel of John is one of the most beloved books in the Bible for many, and I'm not sure if this is allowed, so don't tell anyone, but it's my favorite book of the Bible. Just between us, ok? 

In this first video we did a deep dive on the historical/cultural and literary context of the book of John. My goal in these videos is not only teach you what the text is saying, but to also teach you how to read the Bible faithfully on your own. In this video we talk about the necessity of understanding context, and then we see how the context shapes the meaning of this chapter.

This first chapter serves to elucidate the central claim of Christian theology: Jesus is God. The deity of Christ is perhaps the most important thing that any Christian could learn about, and the book of John is a masterclass for understanding the deity of Jesus. 

In this chapter alone we'll see that John makes the case for the deity of Christ by attributing divine honor, names, and attributes to Jesus. 

References:
Dictionary for Theological Interpretation of the Bible
The IVP Bible Background Commentary: New Testament
Holman Illustrated Bible Dictionary
Moody Bible Commentary

title: Protestant Compares Going to Latin Mass and Novus Ordo
description:
Recently I attended a Latin Mass for the first time, and many of you responded that I should really try a Novus Ordo because it would be easier to understand. Additionally, many of you pointed out that Low Latin Masses are very different than High Latin Masses, and if I wanted to really get the full experience, I should try a High Mass. Well, I did both of these things!

On Sunday, August 30th, I attended the Latin Mass (Extraordinary Form, High) at the beautiful St. John of Cantius Church in Chicago, Illinois. Thanks to the incredible hospitality of many people in the church who had watched my videos, I was provided with a missal and a tour guide who kindly explained the parts of the mass as well as the significance of every part of the church. It was truly an incredible experience, and I hope to share some more of that with you soon. 

Additionally, on that same evening, I attended a Novus Ordo mass at Holy Name Cathedral in Chicago, Illinois. This was my first time going to a Novus Ordo mass, and as a Protestant it felt much more familiar. 

In this video I compare and contrast the two mass types through Protestant eyes and share my thoughts on mass. One thing I learned is that the mass is saturated in Scripture, and there is intentionality in every detail. My hope is that this video will inspire fruitful, healthy dialogue between Protestants and Catholics so that we can work with one another rather than fighting against one another.

title: Class Disparity, Enduring Oppression, and the Centrality of Prayer // James 5
description:
In this week's installment of Life in the Word, we're looking at the last chapter of the book of James. In this chapter we find a prophetic call to repentance for the rich who are profiting off the oppression of the poor. James speaks powerfully about class and wealth disparity, something that is incredibly relevant to our times. Stemming from this, we discuss how Christians should be mindful of implicitly supporting oppressive economic systems, and how we should make sense of our disproportionate wealth as Christians. Next, we looked at how Christians can patiently endure suffering by keeping our eyes on Jesus. Finally we talked about the centrality of prayer in the life of the Christian and the Christian community.


About Life in the Word:
Life in the Word is a weekly Bible Study where we go through one chapter at a time of a book of the Bible. The goal is that it would be a place where your love for the Bible grows, and that scholarly insights meet real world application. This isn't about using fancy words and sounding smart, it's about the beautiful simplicity of opening up the Bible and learning what we can from it. Stay tuned as new episodes drop every Saturday.
