title: My Experience Going to Catholic Mass as a Protestant
description:
Something I'm incredibly passionate about is dialoguing with those I disagree with and doing my best to learn from them despite our differences. When it comes to branches of Christianity that I disagree with, my passion is even more increased. I simply love learning from Catholics and Eastern Orthodox. While we don't see eye to eye on everything, there is so much that we do agree on that can form the basis of great unity between Catholics, Protestants, and Eastern Orthodox. 

A little over a year ago I attended a Catholic men’s group for several months, and recently I made a video describing some of the things I learned with the goal of promoting healthier and more productive dialogue between Protestants and Catholics. It has quickly become my most popular video to date, and I’ve absolutely loved many of the conversations that it has sparked. It has over 1,000 comments so far, and one of the most common pieces of feedback I received, aside from enough book recommendations to fill a library and more than a small army of people encouraging me to subscribe to Lizzie Answers, was that I should go to a Catholic Mass. I love trying and learning new things, and it seemed like good advice given the kind of videos I make, so I decided to do it. Plus, I’m so grateful for all the encouragement you all have given me from that video, so taking a piece of your advice as a gesture of goodwill felt like the least I could do. 

The first matter was figuring out where to go. I live in downtown Chicago, so there’s really no shortage of options. Initially, I wanted to check out an Eastern Catholic Church because I find them particularly interesting, in no small part due to the fact that two of my favorite Catholic YouTubers, Matt Fradd and Trent Horn, are of that persuasion. After a quick Google search, I came across St. John of Cantius Church which Google tried to tell me was Eastern Catholic, though it turns out they’re Roman Rite. Anyway, I decided that on account of it being both beautiful and close by, I’d go with that one. Unfortunately, that wasn’t the final decision I had to make. Because of COVID-19, I had to RSVP for a service, and then I realized that they had different kinds, which forced me to google what on Earth Extraordinary vs Ordinary Form was. After some more googling, I felt like I had it vaguely figured out, and it worked out that on Saturdays they only had Extraordinary form in the morning, so that eased my decision making. I’m sure some people will tell me that I picked the wrong church or service or both, and that’s totally fine, but you have to start somewhere, right?

I'm truly so grateful for all of your support for this channel, and I hope that this video can continue to promote healthy and productive dialogue between Christians of various branches. May we all strive for unity in Jesus.

title: God's Grace in the Middle of Our Weakness and the Futility of Our Planning
description:
Welcome back to another week of Life in the Word! This week we found ourselves in James chapter 4, exploring two key concepts: how Christians can combat the war within themselves and how our planning is often futile. In the middle of this crazy year, I think we can all relate to the latter point. Chances are, you had plans for this year, and they got radically changed. James gives us insight into how little control we truly have, an uncomfortable idea, yet we can find hope and purpose in the midst of this. In fact, you might even find it liberating. In the first half of James, we explore how often times we struggle between our old self and our new self, between worldliness and the kingdom of God, and we find that in the midst of our struggles and sin, God has MORE grace. 

Whether you're new to studying the Bible or have been doing it for years, Life in the Word provides you with opportunities to learn more about what the Bible is saying in context and how that can help shape the way you see the world and live your every day life.

title: How I Ended Up at Bible College and Making Christian YouTube Videos
description: This is my story. In the church world, we call these "testimonies," but "story" will suffice for now. Today, I wanted to share with you my story of trusting Jesus and how that has brought me to Moody Bible Institute in Chicago, IL, ministry, YouTube, and so much more. So many of you have been supporting this channel, and I wanted to take a moment to share with you a bit more about myself and how I've ended up where I am. My hope is that this video will encourage you as well as provide meaningful background to who I am as you watch my other videos. My story has deeply shaped how I see the world and my relationship with God. The truth is, none of us come to God as blank slates. Our personal stories and experiences shape our faith, and God meets us in the messy middle of it all. If you're wondering how to keep your faith when you grow up in the church, maybe my story will help. In this video I share how I nearly walked away from the faith and the church, and what ultimately kept me coming back. This is a story of great weakness and greater grace. I hope it inspires you to take your next step in your journey of following Jesus.

title: Teaching, Taming the Tongue, and the Nature of Wisdom in James 3
description:
The book of James is full of practical wisdom for our everyday lives. As we continue in our study of the book of James, this week we find ourselves in chapter 3, exploring the themes of who should teach in the church, the importance of our words, and what true wisdom looks like. I hope that this video inspires you to take your next step in your journey of following Jesus. Whether you're trying to discern if you should be a spiritual teacher, you want to use your words more wisely, or you're wondering what wisdom is really all about, this video is for you.

title: My Experience Going to a Mosque as a Christian
description:
One of my great convictions is that we're called to love those who we disagree with. A little over a year ago, in preparation for teaching a series on different faiths, I found myself sitting across the table from a group of Muslims at a local mosque. During my time at the mosque I was able to hear from these people about what it's like to be a Muslim in the United States, how they experience prejudice, and so much more. Most importantly, we talked about how Christians and Muslims can work together to build a better world. 

This wasn't about glossing over our differences. This was about bringing them to the light and loving one another in the midst of them. The love Jesus calls his followers to isn't simply a love of those who look like you, think like you, and believe like you. The love Jesus calls us to is a radical love that sees everyone as neighbor and calls us to love across the lines that we draw in the sand between us.

title: Is Sola Fide Biblical?
description:
Justification by faith alone is a pillar of Protestant theology. Next to sola scriptura, sola fide might be the most famous of the reformation "sola's." As one might expect, this has been a MAJOR point of contention between Protestants and Catholics over the years. In this video, we're looking at James chapter 2, one of the most difficult passages of Scripture for Protestants because James explicitly says that we are saved by WORKS. However, it's not like we Protestants just weren't aware of this. So, can sola fide stand up against James 2? Who's right when it comes to justification, Catholics or Protestants?

Every week in our Life in the Word videos we seek to unpack the Bible one chapter at a time. This week is much heavier on theology than most weeks, but I hope you enjoy it. In the first have, we discuss the radical nature of class relations in Christianity, then we pivot to the controversy over justification by faith alone. 

After looking at the Catechism of the Catholic Church, the Council of Trent, a quote from Pope Benedict, a quote from Calvin, Luther's background, and of course, the text itself, I came to a conclusion that might equally offend Catholics and Protestants.... sorry. Perhaps it's naive, but I just really don't think Catholics and Protestants are that far off when it comes to justification. In fact, with some semantic nuance, I think we can find common ground. 

TIME STAMPS:
00:00 - Intro
04:31 - Class Relations in Christianity (James 1:1-13)
08:07 - Sola Fide 
21:46 - Conclusion

title: How Meeting an Eastern Orthodox Priest Changed my Protestant Theology
description:
Last year I sat down with an Eastern Orthodox priest to learn more about Eastern Orthodoxy. As a lifelong Protestant, I knew next to nothing about Eastern Orthodoxy. It didn't take long for me to realize that I was way in over my head. This priest, Father Mastakas, could cite councils, creeds, and church fathers fluently, and I was left with my head spinning. Luckily, I admitted that growing up in a Protestant church, we never talked about this stuff. I told him that I was lost, and I was going to need him to explain some things to me... preferably like I was a child. Kindly, he obliged, and it was in this meeting with an Orthodox priest that my interest in the Church Fathers and Patristics was ignited. Ever since, I have been fascinated by church history and all there is to learn from the Church Fathers. If I had never left my Protestant bubble, I might not have learned all of this. While I'm not a convert to Orthodoxy and don't plan on becoming one, I recognize that there is so much that Protestants like me can learn from our Orthodox brothers and sisters in Christ. In this video I want to tell invite you into my journey of expanding my theological horizons and learning to engage with people I disagree with. 

Church I went to: Saint Peter and Paul Greek Orthodox Church, Frederick, MD. 

A huge thank you to Father George Mastakas. Your kindness and patience with me that day is so greatly appreciated.

title: The Difference Between Knowing Stuff ABOUT God and FOLLOWING Jesus
description: The book of James is one of the most controversial books of the Bible. Famously, Martin Luther once called it an "Epistle of Straw" and long before that, it was one of the "disputed books" of the New Testament Canon. So, what's it all about? What is there in the book of James that we can learn from? In this video we do a deep dive on the background of the book of James and its original context. Then, we explore three key ideas from the first chapter. We're looking at how to consider trials joy, how to be quick to listen, slow to speak, and slow to get angry, and we're exploring the importance of not just knowing stuff about God, but actually following Jesus. There's a lot to learn here, and I hope you enjoy!

title: Trusting God When Everything is Going Wrong // Habakkuk 3 Bible Study
description:
How do we trust God when our life is falling apart? What do we do when everything is going wrong? In the book of Habakkuk we read about a man receiving the worst news, and in the midst of it, he chooses to trust God. In this week's episode of Life in the Word we're wrapping up our series on the book of Habakkuk. In this series we've done a deep dive on how to read biblical prophecy in context. This book shows us a fascinating dialogue between Habakkuk the prophet and God concerning injustice and making sense of God's actions. I hope that by reading this book you gain confidence in God and increase your faith so that you can weather any storm that comes to you.

title: Our Long Distance Experience and Advice
description:
Relationships can be hard, and maintaining a healthy relationship over long distance can make it much harder. In this video, Eliza and I are going to share our experience of dating long distance, and what we've learned. In this video you'll hear how we've tried to prioritize not only our relationship with each other over long distance, but also our relationship with God. We're going to share some of our best Christian dating tips including how to pray as a couple, something that has really helped us. We also talk about communication, trust, and healthy habits in a long distance relationship. If you're looking for long distance tips, especially from a Christian perspective, then this video is for you. 

A huge thank you to Elle for agreeing to do this video. You're amazing. 

About us:
Eliza and I met in the fall of 2017. She was 16 and I was 18 at the time. Then, we officially started dating at the beginning of 2018, and we were by then 17 and 19. Today, we've been dating for just about two and a half years, and we've learned a lot along the way. We have a lot more to learn, and we're by no means experts, but we love to share what we've learned with others to help them grow in their relationships. Eliza is a photography major at Shepherd University in West Virginia.

title: Learning to Trust that God is in Control // Habakkuk 2 Bible Study
description:
Last week we left the book of Habakkuk on a cliff-hanger. Habakkuk cried out to God over injustice, and then God responded in a way that he didn't expect. God told him that he was going to raise up the Chaldeans to strike Jerusalem. Not exactly the deliverance Habakkuk was hoping for. Habakkuk protests to God that this is unfair, and we finished last week waiting for the response.

In this week's video we explore God's response to Habakkuk in chapter 2, and we find out that God is well aware of the Babylonian's sins, and he assures Habakkuk that this won't go unpunished and that He is in control. In this chapter we find important lessons on waiting on God, living by faith, and trusting in God's sovereignty.

title: My Christian Meditation Routine
description:
Christian meditation is a powerful yet under-utilized spiritual discipline. In today's video, I'm going to walk you through my simple yet effective approach to Christian meditation. In this video we'll explore the biblical basis for meditation as well as how to meditate well. This form of Christian meditation, while original, is also indebted to the ancient practice of breath prayers. Breath prayers are a form of praying that focuses on repetition of phrases as you inhale and exhale. After watching this video you'll be able to start your own Christian meditation routine and understand the biblical foundation for such a practice. 

Christian meditation is a great way to combat stress and anxiety while helping you memorize Scripture and grow in your faith. I hope it helps you as much as it has helped me.

title: A Primer on Reading Biblical Prophecy in Context // Habakkuk 1
description:
What do we do when we don't understand God's actions? That was the question racing through Old Testament prophet Habakkuk's mind as he took his complaint before God. In this week's episode of Life in the Word, we're exploring the book of Habakkuk and in so doing, we're looking at how to read biblical prophecy in context. 

The Minor Prophets are some of the most neglected books of the Bible. Whether it's personal Bible study or preaching, these books are often looked over in favor of "easier" books, like Paul's letters, the Gospels, or Old Testament narrative. This is understandable. Reading the prophets is hard. Written thousands of years ago in Hebrew poetry, these books force us to flex our exegetical muscles and really work hard. However, it's worth the work. Reading the biblical prophets can be incredibly rewarding, but we must do so carefully. Nothing is more misinterpreted in Scripture than prophecy. My goal for this week's video is two-fold: explain the context and content of Habakkuk, and teach you how to read prophecy wisely.

title: My Summer Reading List (So far) // Church History, Theology, and Fiction
description:
If you know me, you know that I LOVE to read. A couple months ago I posted my Quarantine reading list, and several of you have requested that I make an updated video on what I'm reading, so here it is! *Time Stamps Below*

You'll notice that this list contains a lot more fiction than the last one. That's intentional. For the past few years I've been reading almost exclusively non-fiction, primarily about theology, and a little leadership mixed in. I love these books. However, I realized that I was missing fiction, so I've slowly started reintroducing it into my reading routine. I hope you'll find some books in this list that you might enjoy!

Books Mentioned: 
The Chronicles of Narnia Series by CS Lewis (01:47) - These books were SO fun to read! Walking away from reading these I was reminded of the fact that your never too old for children's books, and that CS Lewis is truly a master of fiction and non-fiction, a rare talent. One of my favorite things was Lewis' reflections on how Aslan (God) is not tame. We can't put God in a box. Yet, Lewis also shows how this truth can be twisted and weaponized. There's so much more to say, but if you haven't read them, read them.

The Underground Railroad by Colson Whitehead (03:48) - What. a. book. This fictional deep dive into America's dark history is a stunning read. Whitehead brilliantly reimagines the Underground Railroad as an actual railroad, and though this is fictional, it will deeply move you to reckon with the horrors of American slavery. If you're looking for a fictional read that can educate you on the history of race in America, look no further. Well deserving of the Pulitzer. 

Gentle and Lowly by Dane Ortlund (05:03) - I loved this one! Ortlund delves into the depths of Christ's heart, showing it to be gentle and lowly, a heart for sinners and sufferers like you and me. I've read many devotional books that leave you feeling the warmth of Christ's love. However, no other book explores Christ's love in such a warm and yet theological way. Ortlund explores what it means for Jesus to be gentle and lowly in heart through Scripture and the writings of the Puritans. Ortlund introduced me to a whole new world of Puritan writers, and I can't wait to explore more. 

The Lost World of Genesis One by John Walton (06:59) - Walton is a master historian of the Ancient Near East, and he uses this knowledge to shed new light on the biblical origin account in Genesis One. The debate over the origin of man is a fierce one, and Walton wades into this with precision and keen intellect. Showing that the ancient Israelites would've viewed creation accounts through a functional ontology rather than material ontology breaks open a new world of interpretive possibilities in which one doesn't have to decide between faith and science. 

The Lost World of the Torah by John Walton and J. Harvey Walton (08:56) - This book shared many, but not all, of the strengths of The Lost World of Genesis One. Once again, Walton sets this biblical text in its ANE background and in so doing sheds new light on the text. Many of Walton's conclusions I agree with, such as the fact that it's not hermeneutically tenable to divide the Torah between moral and ceremonial law. He also masterfully shows that law functioned much differently in the ANE, and that our interpretations don't usually give justice to that. However, several of his conclusions I couldn't quite get on board with. 

The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes by Suzanne Collins (11:07) - This was just plain fun. I called it in the video a guilty pleasure, but honestly, I feel no guilt over enjoying this. Reading this prequel brought back so many Hunger Games memories, and I thought Collins did a wonderful job with this. 

The Story of Christianity by Justo L. Gonzalez (12:39) - This is a great introduction to church history. I've read both volume 1 (pre-reformation) and volume 2 (post-reformation), and I must say, I prefer the former, though they're both excellent. If you want to learn more about Church History, which I would recommend, this is a great place to start. Very accessible and easy to follow. 

Dominion by Tom Holland (13:53) - Holland is a masterful writer of history, and in this retelling of the growth of Christianity and its profound impact on the world, he weaves together the story in an eminently readable fashion. This is not a textbook listing facts and dates. This is the story of people in the globe-spanning story of Christianity. This is history being told at its finest.

title: Philippians 4 Bible Study
description:
This week we're exploring Philippians 4, looking at one of the most misquoted verses in all of Scripture (and trust me, that's a tough title to earn), some Christian meditation motivation, and also a potential antidote to anxiety. This is our last week in the book of Philippians, and it's been such a pleasure going through it with you! I hope that in this video you can learn what Philippians 4:13 means IN CONTEXT (spoiler alert: it has to do with contentment, not Football games). I hope that in our meditation section you can learn about the foundation of Christian meditation and how you can harness the power of biblical positive thinking. When it comes to anxiety, we all deal with it to varying degrees, but in Philippians 4 we find a biblical approach to fending off anxiety based upon the knowledge of God's presence.

title: Talk Less, Listen More, Gain Wisdom // How Listening Leads to Wisdom
description:
We live in a time where opinions abound and understanding is nowhere to be found. With shorter than ever attention spans, its becoming more and more rare to be truly listened to, and wisdom sometimes feels frighteningly absent. In this video I want to advocate in minimalism in speech (thanks, John Mark Comer). What I mean by that is I want us to talk less, listen more, and in so doing, we will gain wisdom. There is no wisdom where there is no listening, and there is no listening, when we won't cease to talk. One of the greatest gifts you can give people is your full attention because to listen is to love and to love is to listen. We've all been told to think before we talk, what if we actually tried it. In this video, we explore these concepts through the advice of the biblical book of Proverbs, and I hope you walk away equipped to have better conversations, be a better listener, and be able to say things that are actually meaningful. If you want to be a person that people listen to when you're talking, try listening first and gaining wisdom.

title: Righteousness by Faith in Philippians 3
description:
In this week's episode of Life in the Word, we're exploring Philippians chapter 3 where Paul explores, righteousness by faith, the relationship of faith and works, our heavenly citizenship, and more! As in all of our Life in the Word videos, we start with some background to the text, this week exploring the life of Paul and how that plays into this chapter. Specifically we look at three ideas:
1) Paul was Jewish
2) Paul was a Pharisee
3) Paul was a Roman citizen
All of these aspects play into who he was and how he wrote. Then, we explore three key ideas:
1) Righteousness by faith and how that interacts with works
2) How we're all a work in progress
3) How our allegiance is to Jesus and our citizenship is in his kingdom.
I hope through all of these things you're given practical application for your every day life, including the realization that it's not what you do that defines you, you don't have to earn your salvation, there's grace for you as a work in progress, and you are to live as a heavenly citizen. 

About Life in the Word:
Life in the Word is a weekly Bible Study where we go through one chapter at a time of a book of the Bible. title: A Protestant Goes to a Catholic Bible Study... Here's What I Learned
description:
Growing up as a Protestant I had a certain perspective on Catholicism. All that was challenged when I went to a Catholic Bible study for a few months and got to see firsthand what being a practicing Catholic looks like. In this video I share with you my experience as an Evangelical Protestant going to a Catholic Bible study and what I learned from that. During this time I learned that there's a big difference between nominal Catholics and practicing Catholics, a difference many Protestants don't always pick up on. Often times Protestants judge Catholicism based on unfair caricatures. Despite my assumptions, I learned that Catholics do in fact read the Bible, and that a Catholic Bible Study isn't an oxymoron. I also realized that I'm still quite comfortable being a Protestant, despite the fact that Catholicism isn't nearly as weird as I thought. My challenge to you is to engage in conversations with Catholics and realize the biases and false narratives you have about Catholicism. By attending a Catholic Bible study and meeting sincere, practicing Catholics, my view of Catholicism changed. I learned a lot about Catholicism, and maybe even more about myself and my own false beliefs about Catholicism. This isn't the end of the conversation about Catholicism. What we need is more healthy dialogue between Catholics and Protestants, not just arguments based on half-baked caricatures. Hopefully this is a step in the right direction. 

Church I went to: St Michael's Catholic Church in Mt. Airy, MD.
Study I did: That Man Is You by Paradisus Dei

A huge thank you goes out to some of the awesome Catholics I met while at St. Michael's. You all represented the Catholic Church well and welcomed me in with open arms.

title: How to Achieve Unity in the Church (and other things)
description:
In this week's episode of Life in the Word we're exploring the fascinating and puzzling chapter of Philippians 2. In our study we'll cover Paul's vision for unity in the Church and how he links that to humility, we'll talk about the much debated "Kenosis passage" which is a pre-Pauline hymn from the early church talking about Jesus emptying himself and not considering equality with God something to be grasped, and finally we'll explore how our work and God's work go together in salvation. It's a lot of ground to cover, but I hope you find it all both accessible and actionable. It's a wonderful chapter, so let's dive in!

title: What Does the Bible Say About Race and Racism?
description:
Much needed conversations on race and racism are now being had in homes, churches, streets, and every other space. For far too long, our churches and communities have been silent as our minority brothers and sisters have suffered the atrocity of racism. As we navigate these overdue conversations on race and racism, we as followers of Christ would do well to ask the question: what does the Bible say about race and racism? That's what we do in this video. In this Christian response to racism, we're doing two things. First we are exploring a biblical theology of race which is grounded in Genesis 1, informed by the message of Jesus, and culminates in the vision of the kingdom of God being a multi-ethnic people group consisting of people from every nation, tribe, and tongue. Second, we are looking at how Christians should respond to racism. I hope this conversation helps you to gain a better understanding of how to think about race biblically, how to handle privilege, and how to respond to racism. Key to this conversation is the idea of eschatology. If you didn't think eschatology and race went together, think again. If you have to google "eschatology" no judgement. 

Included below are timestamps for your convenience:

title: To Live is Christ and to Die is Gain // Philippians 1 Bible Study
description:
Philippians is an incredible book, and this week we’re jumping into chapter 1, exploring a few things, not least of which is Paul’s famous claim, “to live is Christ and to die is gain.” In this series, Life in the Word, my goal is to allow us to have time to simply open up the Bible together and learn from it, seeing how it applies to our lives. This stems from the conviction that the Bible is an overarching redemptive narrative that leads to Jesus and propels forth into the present with transformative power for our lives. As a Bible nerd, I love sharing whatever I can with you to help you grow. In this video in particular, we explore three concepts:
1) How God’s sovereignty is at work in our lives, even in difficult circumstances.
2) How Paul connects love and wisdom, painting a holistic picture of Christian faith.
3) How Paul could claim (and you can too) that to live is Christ and to die is gain. 
My hope is that you walk away from this video not only having learned some new ideas but feeling empowered to live a life that more closely conforms to the life of Jesus and that you have increased confidence in how to read the Bible and apply it to your life. If you’re looking for an accessible, practical Bible study, Life in the Word is for you!

title: Hawk Nelson Frontman, Jonathan Steingard, Has Left the Faith // How to Respond to Deconversions
description:
It seems that Christian culture is seeing one deconversion story after another, and the most recent story is that of Jonathan Steingard, the frontman of the band Hawk Nelson, who recently announced that he no longer believes in God. In this video, we explore how Christians can respond to apostasy, or in other terms, how Christians can respond to people leaving the faith. It's a sad thing when people leave the faith, but Christians need to respond in love, showing people who walk away that they are loved unconditionally by God and by the Christian community. Likewise, as Christians we need to create safe spaces for people to doubt and ask questions, as well as being more rigorous in learning answers to difficult questions like, if God is good, why is there evil? Or, is the Bible really true? Why is God so violent in the Old Testament? None of these questions are new, and neither are there answers. It's on us to put in the time to make sense of how to answer these questions. In the meantime, we never forget that love is often much more powerful than reason, though we need both.

title: A Christian Response to the Death of George Floyd and Police Brutality
description:
On Monday, May 25, 2020, George Floyd died as the result of a Minneapolis police officer kneeling on his neck for minutes. As Christians, we cannot turn a blind eye to injustice. However, for many Christians, conversations around "social justice" have become taboo. Social justice has been determined by some to be too left-wing (apparently Jesus was a Republican.... *sarcasm*), too worldly, a distraction to the gospel, etc. For others, social justice is the gospel. In this video, I walk you through a biblical theology of justice, exploring how Christians should think about injustices and what we should do. This is not meant to be a definitive video. There are so many things I couldn't get into without making this video too long. This is not a polemic against police officers. This is not white-shaming. This is not even really a video about politics. This is a video about how Christians are called to love God and love our neighbor, and that loving our neighbor looks like standing up for the marginalized, the oppressed, and the downtrodden, even when it's difficult or unpopular. When it comes to cases like this, we should all be concerned about the pattern of black men being killed at the hands of police officers. This is deeply troubling. I think this would trouble Jesus, and therefore it should trouble us. If you're willing to be a little uncomfortable and explore what the Bible has to say about injustice, this video is for you.

title: How Seemingly Small Acts of Obedience Can Have a HUGE Impact
description:
We've made it to the end of Ruth! In this week's episode of Life in the Word we're exploring Ruth chapter 4, and we center our discussion around 3 key ideas. The first idea is that we need to trust God over our fears. In this story, we see how the unnamed kinsman-redeemer backs out of redeeming Ruth because he's scared of what this will do to his inheritance. If only he had trusted God,  he could've been part of God's incredible plans for Ruth. We too must choose faith over fear and step into what God is calling us to. The second idea we explore is that we need to adopt a long view, recognizing that present difficulties don't mean God has abandoned us. We must trust God in the process. Persevere through times of difficulty with the hope that you have in Christ. The final point we explore is that there is no small act of obedience. Through Ruth, Boaz, and Naomi's "small" acts of obedience, God brings about GREAT things, specifically through the birth of King David. We all must realize that there is no small act of obedience, and God has plans for your faithfulness.

title: The Danger of Loving Ministry More Than God
description:
I love ministry. I've worked in ministry full-time and part-time, and I can hardly remember a time when I wasn't volunteering at a church. I love seeing the local church grow, and I'm passionate about creating churches that are impactful. I love ministry. However, my hope is, I love God more. I hope the same is true for you. 

Something I've noticed recently is that it is so easy to find ourselves slowly becoming more interested in doing things for God rather than loving God. In other words, often times we love ministry more than God. We love growing churches more than we love God. We spend more time studying celebrity pastors and big churches than God's Word. It's not a good place to be. My goal in this video isn't to create a false dichotomy between God and ministry. I am not anti-ministry. Far from it. However, we should be doing ministry out of the overflow of our love for God. Ministry is a great servant and a lousy master. It can become easy to worship ministry, to idolize ministry, but when we do we burnout. Given the current state of affairs, it's not surprising that ministry burnout is so high. I hope that by tracing the story of Gideon and the Golden Ephod in Judges 8, we'll be able to see the danger of loving ministry more than God as well as be able to see a way forward.

title: Breath Prayers: An Ancient Christian Antidote to Anxiety
description:
We live in an age of worry. Anxiety seems to plague nearly everyone in some way or another. The breath prayer, an ancient Christian form of prayer, could be a tool in your arsenal for fighting anxiety and stress. Breath prayers are a simple way of praying where you inhale, saying or thinking one line of Scripture, and exhale, saying the following line. Breath prayers are most commonly associated with the Jesus Prayer, a famous prayer out of the Eastern Orthodox tradition where people inhale, saying "Lord Jesus Christ, Son of God" then exhale saying, "have mercy on me, a sinner." However, this form of praying, breath prayers, can be adapted for more than just the Jesus Prayer. It's great for praying Scripture of all kinds. Additionally, it is a contemplative form of prayer that is incredibly peaceful, helping you focus your mind, heart, and soul on God. Also, breath prayers allow you to meditate on Scripture and work towards praying continually. If you're looking for a way to grow in your faith and want to find new ways to pray this could be for you.

In this video, we cover what breath prayers are, the history of breath prayers, why you should try breath prayers, and how you can implement them. Plus, at the end there is time for a guided breath prayer/christian meditation. I think you'll really enjoy it.

title: The Power of Reputation and God's Radical Social Vision in Ruth 2
description:
In this week's episode of Life in the Word we're looking at Ruth chapter 2. In this chapter we find God's radical social vision taking care of the poor, and we also see the power of reputation. A few things that we cover in this video are the background of reaping in Ruth, specifically looking at the Old Testament vision of taking care of the poor. Additionally we cover the background of Levirate marriage and how that works in Ruth 2. Then, I give you two key takeaways from this chapter, specifically God's care for the poor and the power of reputation. Just as God cares for the poor, Christians too are called to be mindful of the poor and bless them out of the blessings we've received. When it comes to reputation, we look at how our reputation arises out of our private lives. What we do in private determines who we become in public. Our private faithfulness often results in public blessing, just as it does here in Ruth. With all of this, we see that Ruth 2 is a jam-packed chapter filled with practical insights for your life and interesting background into the Old Testament social vision.

title: Bible Commentaries: What They Are and How to Use Them (4 Types, 4 Tips)
description:
Do you even need commentaries? Hasn't God made the Bible easy to understand so you don't need commentaries? What are commentaries anyway? In this video, I answer these questions, plus I give you four tips on how you should use Bible commentaries as well as insight into why you should use them. To put it briefly, in this video you will learn about 4 types of Bible commentaries and get 4 tips on how to use Bible commentaries to help you in your personal Bible study. If you're looking to go deeper in your Bible study, or you just recognize that you need some help when it comes to reading the Bible, commentaries are a great tool. I hope this video helps you gain a better understanding of what Bible commentaries are and how you can use them effectively.

title: The Chosen Review: Does it add too much that's not in the Bible?
description:
Should Christians watch the chosen? Is The Chosen biblically accurate? The Chosen is a new T.V. series by Dallas Jenkins about the life of Jesus, and the disciples. It is a crowdfunded project that seeks to bring the story of Jesus to life through film. Recently the first season launched on YouTube, and it has received glowing reviews. However, in the midst of that, some people are worried that it goes too far in adding details that simply aren't found in the Bible. For some, it crosses the line and deviates too far from the gospel accounts. It's true, there's a lot in The Chosen that's not in the Bible. While this is the greatest weakness to some, it's also the greatest strength of the show. The Chosen does a great job of bringing the characters to life in a way that is biblically faithful, even though not explicitly in the gospels. Let me explain. The Chosen is not a word for word retelling of the gospels. It's not trying to be. The Chosen is taking the Bible stories and creatively filling in details that are not intended to be infallibly correct, but are historically, culturally, and biblically informed. The series allows us to imagine what could have been not merely, what we already know is true (though it shows that as well). As long as you're not trying to replace the Bible with this show and counting on it to be infallible, inerrant, inspired, etc., then I think you'll love this show and get a lot out of it. 

Check out The Chosen here: https://studios.vidangel.com/the-chosen

title: Overcoming Temptations, Grey Areas, and Living a Christian Life
description:
Often times we find ourselves torn between what we know we should do, and what we want to do. This is especially true in what we call "grey areas." We often feel that if the Bible doesn't specifically say we can't or shouldn't do something, then we're good to go. However, often times in these grey areas there's this feeling that we probably shouldn't do this. The fact is, when it comes to temptation for Christians and knowing what to do, it's actually quite simple. It's not easy, but it's simple. The problem is, we often think in terms of how close we can get to the line without sinning. We think we know what's best, so we try to go as far as we can with what we want to do without sinning and upsetting God. The thing is, that betrays a completely wrong way of viewing sin. Sin is not just breaking God's commands and doing what he says not to do, though it is certainly that. A wholistic, biblical view of sin is actually much bigger. Sin, in the biblical sense, is "missing the mark." In this case, everything that falls short of God's design for our lives is sin. Rather than tip-toeing through temptation, we ought to be running towards righteousness. Rather than asking if something is a sin, we should ask if it glorifies God. If it doesn't, don't do it. It's simple. It's not easy, but it's simple.

Resources for going deeper: 
Westminster Shorter Catechism
Romans 6:3-4
2 Corinthians 5:17
Galatians 2:20
John 10:10
Bible Project: Sin

title: My Experience Reading Calvin as an Arminian
description:
In the church I grew up in, "Calvinism" was a bad word. My basic understanding of Calvinism was that it made God to be a moral monster, it made humans robots, and overall it was just bad and not to be messed with. That was more or less the extent of my interaction with Calvinism growing up, and even as I learned a little more, I always had a sense it should be kept at an arm's length. Then I went to Bible College. In Bible college (Moody Bible Institute) I started meeting Calvinists and realizing that for the most part, they're not crazy, believe in a loving God, and are generally nothing like what I was told to believe. The biggest challenge to my Arminianism and my childhood views of Calvinism was actually reading Calvin's Institutes for myself. In this video, my goal is not to debate Calvinism vs Arminianism (I know, some of you might be disappointed now, but if you've read the description this far, the least you can do is watch the video). Rather, my goal is to promote honest conversation between Arminians and Calvinists. No matter which side of the debate you fall on, I think we can all learn from the other side, and hopefully in so doing realize that this really isn't about sides. We're all on the same team, disagreements and all. My challenge to you is twofold: first, be more faithful to Scripture than your theological system and second, engage with the other side at the source. If you're a Calvinist, read Wesley and Arminius. If you're an Arminian, read Calvin. There's a lot to be learned from both Calvinists and Arminians, if we're humble enough to learn.

title: The Quarantine Ministry Opportunity that's Being Missed by Most
description:
As Churches and Christians in general adapt to life in quarantine and the world of online church, many ministries are innovating in exciting ways, yet most people are neglecting one of the biggest opportunities for ministry growth and personal growth in this season. You see, while we work ourselves into the ground making online church happen and trying to make the most out of this season, many people are missing the blessing in disguise during COVID-19: the opportunity to grow deep roots, to seek personal time with God, and focus on our faith. The truth is many of us have fallen more in love with ministry than God himself. We're obsessed with doing things for God, but we neglect spending intentional time with God. This is a dangerous trend and inevitably leads toward ministry burnout and burnout in our faith. During coronavirus quarantine, the opportunity we all should be taking advantage of is sitting at the feet of Jesus and deepening our love for him. This is what will bring real results and real growth. We must be willing to do the deep, personal work rather than seeking fast results in our faith and ministry. This is the way of slow, but significant growth. In this video we talk about all these things, and then we filter them through the story of Mary and Martha in Luke 10 where we see that sometimes only one thing is necessary: sitting at the feet of Jesus and listening.

title: Quarantine Screen Time vs. Quiet Time Challenge (3 Levels)
description:
Many of us can spend hours and hours on our phones scrolling through social media, yet we struggle to spend even 15 minutes reading our Bibles or praying. In this video I give you a challenge at three different levels of spending more time in your quiet time than on screen time. The first level of the challenge is to spend more time in your quiet time than you do reading/watching the news. In this time, it's easy to be filled with anxiety over watching the news, and taking on this challenge will really help you find peace. The second level of the challenge is to spend more time in your quiet time than reading/watching the news and social media combined. Surely we can all agree that reading the Bible is more productive than scrolling through Instagram, yet we spend much more time on social media than reading the Bible/doing our quiet time. This might be challenging, but I think you'll really enjoy it. The final level of the challenge is the most difficult, and that is to spend more time in your quiet time than all of your screen time. If you need to make exception for work/school, go ahead, but the point is to really pay attention to how we're spending our time during quarantine and make adjustments. Don't waste your time that you have during quarantine. Use this time of quarantine to grow in your faith and deepen your relationship with God. You'll be glad you did it.

title: What is Maundy Thursday and What Can We Learn from it?
description:
What is Maundy Thursday? If you're like me, it's not a holiday you grew up hearing much about. Liturgical holidays weren't really a part of the evangelical tradition I grew up in. Maybe that's the case for you too. However, Maundy Thursday has much to teach us. Maundy Thursday shows us what it means to love and serve as a Christian because it points us back to the example of Jesus. Maundy Thursday, the Thursday before Easter commemorates the night that Jesus shared the Last Supper with his disciples, washed the disciples feet, and gave his famous mandate to love one another as he had loved them. In this video, I give you a very brief explanation of Maundy Thursday (from an Evangelical Protestant perspective) as well as encourage you to reflect on this day and embody what we see Jesus doing. All Christians are called to service. All Christians are called to love. However, that is still a bit vague. Maundy Thursday helps clarify what Christian love and service really look like.

title: Finding Joy in the Middle of Hard Times
description:
This is the day that the Lord has made. We may not understand why we are where we are, but this is the day the Lord has made, so we are called to rejoice in the midst of it. With coronavirus still spreading rampantly, it can be difficult to find joy in our daily, quarantined realities, but as Christians, we always have reason to hope and find joy. In this video we look at both Psalm 118:24 and 1 Thessalonians 5:18 to see what the Bible has to say about finding joy in all circumstances. Being joyful doesn't mean that we ignore the difficult parts of life. It doesn't even mean that we don't experience sadness. Being joyful means we are consciously grateful for the ways God is blessing us, no matter what our circumstances look like. I hope this video encourages you in these times. title: Christians, Stop Reflecting on the Coronavirus for a Moment
description: I'll admit, my default is to reflect, deconstruct, analyze, and theologize rather than feel, experience, and live through a moment. We need reflection on the Coronavirus. We need to think theologically about Coronavirus. These are all good things. But we also need to feel. We need to lament. We need to cry out to God about Coronavirus. It's ok to be upset with God. It's ok to even be angry with God. In this video, I wanted to take a brief pause from reflecting on the coronavirus and give you permission and space to lament, to feel all that you're feeling. We must remember that we do not work out our salvation and live as Christians in a disembodied thought-world. We are not Gnostics. We are not brains on a stick. We are human BEINGS. And there is a time to mourn. These are heavy times. We are in this together.

title: I Read the Entire Bible in 90 Days... and You Can Too (30 Minutes a day)
description:
Last semester I read the ENTIRE Bible in just 90 days, and I found out it's not as hard as you might think. In this video I give you three things I learned from reading the Bible in 90 days plus tips on how you can read the entire Bible in just 90 days as well. Sometimes you want to go slow when reading the Bible. That's what I had always been taught, and for the most part it's good advice, but sometimes reading the Bible quickly actually helps us pick up on things we would've missed, like how the Bible is a unified story that leads to Jesus. Reading the Bible quickly will help you see how all of the Bible points to Jesus, and it's a really cool thing once you see that for yourself. I also learned from this experience the value of listening to the Bible. For much of history, people learned the Bible by hearing it read aloud, and there's something powerful in hearing the Bible audibly read. Most importantly I learned that you absolutely can read the entire Bible, even in a time as short as 90 days. The crazy thing is it only takes about 30 minutes a day. Last of all, shoutout to Dr. Steven Sanchez at Moody Bible Institute for encouraging... well, requiring, me to do this. 

Here's a Reading Guide: https://csbible.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/CSB90-DayReadingPlan.pdf

title: What Coronavirus is Teaching me about Our Plans and God's Control
description:
The phrase, "Lord Willing" which often gets added as an asterisk to statements always seemed a bit like empty Christianese, a cliche that's a relic of the past. However, as I began hearing all of my professors at Moody Bible Institute say it, I began to feel that maybe this saying actually had something to it. Then Coronavirus struck. Seemingly everyone's plans were abruptly changed, and we were giving a jarring reminder that God, not our plans, is in control. Suddenly, I became aware that this phrase, rather than being meaningless, actually portrayed a deep humility by recognizing that God is in control and we must hold our plans loosely. This caused me to dig back into James 4:13-16 where we are instructed not to say with confidence what we will do tomorrow, next month, or next year, but rather to recognize that we will only do that which the Lord wills. In the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, we all need to reflect on the fact that we are not in control. And for what it's worth, that's actually a really good thing. My hope is this video will inspire you to adopt this little phrase into your vocabulary and allow it to shape you, humbling you to recognize God's sovereignty over all things.

title: Simple Tips to Not Panic over the Coronavirus as a Christian
description:

In this video we explore that idea plus give you some practical tips on avoiding panic over the corona virus. These tips include setting aside only specific times to check the news, turning off news notifications (you don't need that anxiety), and removing the news widget from your phone. Right now, many people are panicking over the Corona Virus, but as Christians we should fix our eyes on Jesus, the Prince of Peace. When we do this, we as Christians will find peace instead of panic, faith instead of fear. How we respond as Christians to the Corona Virus will say a lot about our faith, and we're living in a moment that can be seen as an opportunity to grow in our trust, or as something that will take our eyes off of Jesus.

title: Fastest Way to Get Better at Reading the Bible + Demo
description:
Reading the Bible is a skill, and like anything else, getting better takes time. However, if you do want to improve your Bible study, the best thing you can do is to ask more questions. Seriously. That's it. When you're reading the Bible, there's often many things that you don't understand that you never even think to ask questions about and learn more. If you start asking more questions, you will get more out of your Bible study and the Bible will start to come alive to you. While there's no secret to becoming great at reading the Bible overnight, if you do this you will begin to see improvement right away.

title: 5 Bible Study Tips to Read the Bible More Effectively
description:
Want to get better at studying the Bible? If you implement these 5 C's of Bible study into your quiet time, you will be on track for going much deeper and learning more from your Bible study. Many people wonder, how they can study the Bible for themselves, and Bible study can be intimidating at times, but it doesn't have to be. Many of these Bible study tips are things I have picked up in my time as a Theology student at Moody Bible Institute as well as from my own journey of reading the Bible for many years now. In these tips we talk about the importance of context for reading the Bible well, asking more questions, reading with others, and much more. I hope they help you grow in your confidence with reading the Bible and inspire you to grow in your faith. You CAN study the Bible for yourself, and if you follow these tips, you will be ready to interpret the Bible accurately. 

The 5 C's (with timestamps)
1) Read Contextually (01:09)
2) Read Canonically (06:09)
3) Read Consistently (06:30)
4) Read Communally (07:03)
5) Read Curiously (09:09)

Books Mentioned:
Introduction to Biblical Interpretation by William Klein, Craig Blomberg, and Robert Hubbard

title: Super Simple and Effective Bible Study Method + Demo
description:
Reading the Bible can be intimidating, but this super simple but effective method will help you start to get more out of your Bible study right away by simply asking two questions: 
1) What does this passage tell me about God?
2) What does this passage tell me about people?
Just by asking these two simple questions, you can begin seeing how the Bible is relevant to your own life and start to apply Biblical truth to your everyday situations. Reading the Bible doesn't have to be super complicated, and this method reveals how you can start reading the Bible on your own. Whether you're new to reading the Bible or just want to try something different, I hope this method helps you to grow in your confidence in studying the Bible, and more importantly, I hope it helps you grow in your faith. 

Have questions? Let me know in the comments!

title: Christians and the Coronavirus // How Our Response Displays Our Theology
description:
What we truly believe isn't found in our doctrinal statement written in ivory towers, it's not found in what we preach, but truly, if you want to know what someone believes, watch how they live, especially when they're afraid. The world has its eyes on the spread of the Coronavirus (COVID-19) as it spreads across the globe, and many people right now are full of fear, wondering if this pandemic will reach their doorstep. However, how should Christians respond to the Coronavirus? Do our religious beliefs have anything to do with our reaction to a disease? In this video, I share with you my thoughts on how we as Christians should respond to the Coronavirus, encouraging you to think about three main things:
1) Prayer Instead of Panic
2) Choosing Faith Over Fear
3) Speaking and Living Truth
Through these main points we talk about how we view prayer in times of trouble reveals our true thoughts on prayer and God. We also talk about the fact that we as Christians do not live in fear of death, but rather we have hope in Jesus. Finally, we talk about the importance of shining brightly as a city set on a hill amidst these dark times. I hope this video challenges you and inspires you to grow in your love for God and people.

Verses Referenced:
Colossians 3:2
Psalm 23
Acts 20:24
1 John 4:18
James 4:14
Philippians 4:5-6
And a few other loose quotations

title: Can You Love Jesus and Hate the Church?
description:
There seems to be a growing tide of people that say they love Jesus, but they're just not too big of fans of church. Is that ok for Christians? Can Christians love Jesus and hate the church? In this video we explore the connection between loving Jesus and loving the church. I hope by the end of this video you're challenged to see that we must not separate these two ideas: loving God and loving the church. These two things should go hand in hand. Are we hurt by the church at some times? Absolutely. Are churches messy? Absolutely. Do we sometimes not feel like going to church? Absolutely. Do we give up on church? I pray we never do. The goal of this series is to cultivate in us a love for the church that mirrors Christ's love for the church, and it's my hope that this video has moved you towards that, even in some small way.

title: What does Christian Greatness Look Like? // Rediscovering a Biblical Vision of Greatness
description:
In one way or another, all of us desire to be great. In fact, each of us are subtly orienting our lives around our vision of greatness. There's nothing wrong with wanting to be great. However, there are serious consequences to how we choose to define greatness. Biblically speaking, greatness isn't about being at the top of the ladder in wealth, power, prestige, or in fact, any category. Biblically speaking, Christian greatness looks like service that is saturated with humility. Jesus said in Matthew 20:26 that whoever wants to be great must be a servant, and Paul in Philippians 2 urges us to imitate Christ's humility. By all means, I want all of us to be great, but let us strive for this upside-down, paradoxical greatness that is found in humble service to others for the glory of God. For Christians, being great isn't about financial success, achieving your goals, or self-actualizing, as many prosperity gospel messages might want you to think. For Christians, greatness is imitating Christ's humble service.

title: Three Tips for Avoiding and Overcoming Burnout in Church and Ministry
description:
Burnout is a major problem in the life of the church. Maybe you once were excited about serving in the church but before long you found yourself completely burned out. Maybe you're scared that you're on the edge of burnout. In any case, this video is for you! In this video we explore how to avoid and overcome church/ministry burnout. Specifically, we explore three main tips that will hopefully lead you to be maximally effective in your ministry for the long haul. 

Tip One (02:55) - Recognize that burnout often stems from how you use your time outside of ministry. In this tip we explore a bit of the theology of sleep and how recognizing our limitations is actually a profoundly spiritual action. We also talk about taking a sabbath, prioritizing your life so that you seek first the kingdom of God, and how your "no's" strengthen your "yes's."
 
Tip Two (06:46) - Remember your why. In this tip we talked about how remembering why you're in ministry will help you continue in ministry. We also talked about the importance of recognizing that we don't serve FOR God's approval but FROM God's approval. Additionally, we talked about the fact that in Christ we are a new creation, and it is in our very nature to be servants.

Tip Three (08:12) - Strive for sustainability in ministry, not balance. Our culture has become obsessed with the idea of balance, and somehow we've tried to baptize this into a Christian ideal. As Christians we're not called to a balanced life. Instead, we should be looking for sustainability. However, we don't seek sustainability on our own power, but rather we recognize Christ as our sustainer.

title: HOT TAKE: The Saying "Christianity is a Relationship Not a Religion" is Actually Not Helpful
description:
Chances are you've heard this catch phrase repeated ad nauseam by friends, pastors, and maybe yourself. Perhaps you're even quite a big fan of it. In today's video I want to explore why the saying "Christianity is a Relationship Not a Religion" is actually not true/helpful and where it falls short. Far from condemning people who use this (trust me I have said it many times) I want to challenge you to think critically about it and see where it falls short. It's absolutely true that we as Christians have a relationship with God, in fact all of us have SOME type of relationship with God, but to say that this relationship is inherently opposed to religion is simply misguided. Additionally, this phrase can lead us to become too casual in our relationship with God, treating God like a friend or an equal, rather than recognizing God as Lord. I hope this video challenges you and helps you as you continue your journey of following Jesus.

title: Church Isn't a Spectator Sport // Consumer Christianity and the Importance of Serving in Church
description:
For many, church has become little more than attendance at a live speaking engagement with music. Or a concert with a little inspiration sprinkled in. They come in, they go out, mentally rating the service, and that's it. It's no surprise that even many Christians are feeling like church is optional. However, the biblical vision of being a part of the local church is about much more than consuming ideas and inspiration, it's about contributing to the life of the church and the community through service. Today there is a desperate need for Christians to recognize that church isn't a mere spectator sport, but it is something we're called to be actively involved in, getting our hands dirty and devoting ourselves to the life of the church. 

Verses used in this video:
Philippians 2:6-7
Mark 10:45
Matthew 20:31
Matthew 16:18
1 Peter 4:10
Romans 12:11

title: Our Desperate Need of God and the Myth of Self-Sufficiency
description:
Most of us are fond of feeling fiercely independent and entirely self-sufficient. The problem is, not only do we lack real control, but that attitude is opposed to the gospel. The truth is we are in desperate need of God. God is our help and our deliverer, our place of refuge, and our source of strength. Recently as I've been going through the Psalms, I've been convicted of our deep need for God and how our desire to be self-sufficient actually runs contrary to the message of the gospel. In this video, we focus in on Psalm 40:17 which reminds us of how we are poor and needy, yet God takes thought for us. I hope this video reminds you that you don't have to try to take control of everything in your life. God is in control, and humbling as it may be, it's for our good that we aren't the captains of our own destiny.

title: Yes, the Church Has Problems. What are You Going to do to Help? // Church Talk: Deconstructionism
description:
It's no secret that the church has problems. People inside and outside of the church are quite fond of pointing that out. The question for those in the church is, "what are you going to do to help?" It's tempting to spend our days criticizing the church, pointing out all its flaws, and calling it a day. Sometimes we even feel our rampant deconstructionism is a service to the church. In this video, I want to challenge you with the idea that deconstruction is only helpful when it is seen as a means to the end of reconstruction. We can point out the flaws of the church, but if it's not followed by offering solutions, then we're actually choosing to be part of the problem, rather than part of the solution. Far from being a video calling you to leave your church and start something new and "better," I want to challenge you to live into the mess of your church, get your hands dirty, and work to see the church be all that it can be. It's the harder route, but it's the worthwhile route.

title: Why You NEED to get Plugged in at a Church in College // Church Talk
description:
So often Christians grow up going to church, and then they get to college, and even though they still care about their faith, church simply isn't a priority. Maybe the idea of finding a church is intimidating, or maybe you feel like you don't have time. Whatever the case, it's essential to push past these excuses and get plugged in at a local church during college. Attending church isn't an optional part of the christian life. The church is the bride of Christ, and if Jesus was willing to give up his life for the church, we should be able to give up a few hours of sleep for the church. If you're in college or getting ready to go to college and you are wondering how church fits into your college life, this video is for you.

title: It's Time to Get Real with God // Learning to Pray: Praying When Life Sucks and You're Mad at God
description:
Here's the thing, you're facing R-rated problems and you're responding with PG-rated prayers. Your problems are real, yet your prayers are just, well, a little too nice. If you're being honest, your prayers are far from honest. Sound familiar? Maybe you can relate, maybe you can't, but my goal with this video is that by introducing you to the rich genre of lament psalms you could realize that it's ok to express your frustrations to God, to be angry with God and let him know. When life gets hard, we need to run to God in prayer with raw honesty, rather than simply praying empty prayers that our hearts aren't really in or simply ignoring God altogether. Again, I want to be sure you hear me that I'm not saying we should be irreverent, but I am saying God invites us to be honest with him and express our pain, our doubts, and our frustration. 

Church referenced: mosaicchristian.org. Check them out, they're great. If you do, tell them I said hi.

title: How to Step into Your Calling with Confidence // The Subtle Pride of Insecurity
description:
When God calls us to do something, often we respond with all the reasons we can't or are unworthy, just as Moses did in Exodus 3-4. At first glance, this insecurity may seem like humility, yet underneath the surface there it is actually pride not humility. When we focus on what we can't do, we're neglecting all that God can do. More important than our individual gifts, talents, and abilities is God's infinite ability to work in and through us. In fact, this paradigm of our inability and God's ability is at the core of this gospel. In this video, by exploring Exodus chapter 3, we're going to look at how we can step into our calling with confidence, not in what we can do, but what God can do through us, learning that true humility, as C.S. Lewis put it, is not in thinking less of ourselves, but thinking of ourselves less. I hope you enjoy this video and it helps you take the next step in your journey of following Jesus.

title: The Importance of Developing Healthy Christian Habits // A Conversation on Spiritual Disciplines
description:
Our habits play a huge role in who we become. As Christians, it's our responsibility to develop healthy habits so that we can grow in our faith. Too often, spiritual disciplines are viewed as empty rituals and "going through the motions" but what I want to explore in this video is the way that spiritual disciplines can help you grow in your faith and mature as a Christian. As 2 Peter 3:18 says, we should be growing in the grace and knowledge of Jesus. Christians should never be stagnant, but far too many Christians are frustrated with the fact that they're not growing in their faith. If you want to grow in your faith, the first thing to think about is developing habits that will form you into the you that you were created to be. 

In the video I mentioned Dallas Willard, his book Spirit of the Disciplines, and an article going over some of them. Here is that article: https://www.soulshepherding.org/spiritual-disciplines-list/

title: A Conversation about the Persecuted Church // Inspired by the book "Safely Home" by Randy Alcorn
description:
If you're like me, persecution hasn't played a large role in your life, but for many Christians all over the world, persecution is a daily reality. According to Open Doors USA (https://www.opendoorsusa.org/christian-persecution/stories/christian-persecution-by-the-numbers/) 11 people are killed each day for their faith in Jesus. While I feel entirely inadequate to talk about persecution given my lack of experience, I felt that this was a conversation that needs to be had. While I thank God, truly, for the religious freedoms we have, they have also allowed us to become comfortable with "casual Christianity" as though following Jesus was an insignificant choice. In reality, the call to follow Jesus is a radical, life-altering call. Being a Christian means giving our ultimate allegiance to King Jesus and placing Jesus above everything, even our very life. 

This video was inspired by my experience reading the book "Safely Home" by Randy Alcorn, and subsequently the documentary "Sheep Among Wolves" which you can watch for free on YouTube. I'm grateful for these resources and the way they have challenged me.

title: How to Experience True Rest // The Lie We Tell Ourselves about Doing More and Being Busy
description:
Often we find ourselves running ourselves ragged trying to do and be more, but the truth is, nothing we DO defines us. In the long run, it's about what God has already DONE. The key to experiencing true rest is understanding this pivotal idea. We must no longer receive our value from what we do and what we accomplish. Only then will we be able to experience true rest, the kind of rest God desires us to have. In our relationship with God, we don't work harder to earn God's love, we simply love because he first loved us. That is what I call "The Great Reversal" because in most of our relationships we try to do things to earn God's love, but with God he loves us before we do anything. I hope this video helps you experience true peace and rest and in God. Sometimes slowing down is exactly what we need to be reminded of the love and faithfulness of God.

title: What Kind of Things Should We Pray for? // Learning to Pray: "Big Prayers" vs. "Small Prayers"
description:
Alright, so we know we should pray, but what should we pray for? Should we pray big, bold prayers, or simple, small prayers? That's what we're looking at in this video, but the spoiler is, the answer is yes. We should pray for all kinds of things, big and small. This is demonstrated in the Lord's Prayer, when Jesus tells us to pray both for the Kingdom to come on Earth and for our daily bread. The key to understanding what to pray for is recognizing that all good and perfect gifts come from God, so we should pray for anything, big or small. My hope with this video is that it will help you feel more comfortable praying and grow closer in your relationship with God. 

Credit to where it's due: This series was inspired by Pete Greig's book, How to Pray: A Simple Guide for Normal People.

title: How an Ancient Form of Prayer Has Helped My Prayer Life // Learning to Pray: Practical Tips
description:
The Prayer of Examen is an ancient form of prayer developed by St. Ignatius Loyola that focuses on reviewing your day and examining your emotions. In this video I share with you how I implement this form of prayer in a modified version in my own prayer life. The basic outline I present for a prayer of examen in this video is from Pete Greig's book, How to Pray: A Simple Guide for Normal People. Check out that book for more information. For many of us, prayer is hard and a bit unnatural, but this simple form of prayer will help you develop a consistent habit of praying and will allow you to pray longer without even noticing. 

The basic outline I follow is:
Replay - Go back over your day in detail, including the emotions you felt throughout the day. 
Rejoice - Thank God for all He did for you that day. 
Repent - Take note of the sin in your life that day, big and small, and repent before God.
Reboot - Prepare yourself for sleep and the day to come.

title: Should You Talk to God Like a Friend? // Learning to Pray: Balancing Reverence and Intimacy
description:
So how exactly should we talk to God in prayer? Should we talk to God casually? Should we be fearful when praying? These are all very important questions to consider when figuring out how to pray. The thing is, most of us feel we should pray, yet we struggle to actually do it, or we do pray, but we feel our prayer lives are empty. In this video we're going to explore the healthy tension that should exist in our prayer life between reverence and intimacy. On one hand, we're approaching God who is an all-consuming fire and ruler of the cosmos, yet at the same time, he invites us to relate to him as children to a father. I think this balance is demonstrated in the most famous prayer, The Lord's Prayer, as you'll see in the video. This video is the start of a new series, "Learning to Pray," and it's my hope that it would help you find new vitality in your prayer life, turning prayer into a joy rather than an obligation. Have questions? Leave a comment!

Verses:
1 John 3:1
Romans 8:15
Luke 11:1-2
Hebrews 12:29

Sources:

title: Verses of the Week // Key Ideas in 2 Peter
description:
Welcome back to verses of the week, a weekly segment where we explore some of the verses that stood out to me from my week's Bible study. My hope is that these videos provide you not only with insight into the teaching of the Bible, but that they would also inspire you to pick up your Bible and make Bible study a consistent habit in your life. This week we explored the book of 2 Peter, a letter written by the Apostle Peter, one of Jesus' closest followers. We got a little nerdy with this one, talking about key verses for Bibliology (aka the pretentious way to say verses that talk about the nature of the Bible) specifically 2 Peter 1:20-21 and 2 Peter 3:15-16. I challenged you to ask "what is the Bible?" as we explore the interplay of the Holy Spirit and the human authors. We also look at how Paul was considered on par with Scripture. Additionally, we mined the wonderful mystery of what it means to be partakers of the divine nature, being supplied with all we need for life and godliness, as seen in 2 Peter 1:3-8. Finally, we also discuss the Second Coming of Christ, and God's patience shown through that. I hope you enjoy this video, and as always, please reach out with any questions you might have.

title: Faith of the Hands // Elements of Faith: Developing a Holistic Faith of Head, Heart, and Hands
description:
Today we wrap up our three-part series, Elements of Faith, where we've been exploring the three aspects of faith that make up a holistic faith. In this week's episode we're talking about faith of the hands, how true faith expresses itself in works. Often faith and works are pitted against each other, but a better way of viewing it is not faith vs. works but faith that works. Works should be the natural overflow of genuine faith. Faith of the Hands at its core is the visible, tangible expression of faith of the head and heart.

title: How Hymns Are Changing How I See Worship
description:
Growing up, I never listened to hymns. In fact, I've spent 20 years in church, and until recently, I knew hardly any hymns. However, that's beginning to change, and as that changes the way I see worship is changing as well. The truth is, if we can only engage in worship with a specific genre, we might be worshipping that particular expression of worship more than God himself. True worship is about God, not the style of music. Another thing I've found is that hymns which I once thought were boring and lifeless, have some truly beautiful lyrics that communicate rich truths about God. My hope is that through this video you will not only see the beauty of hymns, but more so that you'll realize that worship is less about a particular genre and more about God himself and the posture of our heart towards him.

title: The Most Overlooked Way to Grow in Your Faith and Get Better at Evangelism
description:
According to recent studies, only 13% of Christians have spiritual conversations once a week... For people that say their faith is the most important thing in their life, this is a troubling statistic. Increasingly it seems we've lost the art of spiritual conversations. If we ever want to get better at sharing our faith with people who aren't Christians, we need to start by at least being able to share our faith with Christians. This video is all about regaining our ability to simply talk about our faith and how that will greatly impact our spiritual growth. 

Article referenced: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/13/opinion/sunday/talk-god-sprituality-christian.html?module=inline

title: How Christians Misunderstand Grace
description:

title: There Are No "Boring" Testimonies
description:
Maybe you've been here before, someone gets up and shares their testimony and it'f full of crazy ups and downs and you sit there thinking, "wow, my testimony is so boring." If that's you I can relate! Maybe you grew up in a Christian home, or maybe coming to faith just didn't seem that spectacular for you. Often times we assume that since no one would want to make a movie out of our story, that we therefore have a boring testimony and it can't really be used by God. Maybe you wouldn't say the last part, but you probably live like it's true. In this video I want to encourage you that is so far from the truth. There is no such thing as a boring testimony because your testimony is the story of the God of the universe interacting with you and working in you. 

Verses referenced:
2 Peter 1:3
Philippians 2:12

title: Your Weakness and God's Power // A few thoughts on 2 Corinthians 12:1-10
description:
"Your weakness is the canvas upon which God paints his masterpiece called grace" - these are the words that came to mind when I heard my professor speaking on 2 Corinthians 12. Often times we seek to have everything under control, be the master of our own destiny, and triumph over anything that comes our way through our own power. Because of this, we effectively tell God that we have no need for his grace and his power. However, in 2 Corinthians 12, through the story of the thorn in his flesh, Paul reveals this insight: God's power is made perfect in our weakness. In essence, God's power is seen in our life when we recognize our own weakness and our dependence upon him.

title: Christian Quotes of the Week // Week 2
description:
Want all the best information from Bible college and great Christian books without all the hours of reading? In this series I'm giving you some highlights from great books that we're reading at Moody Bible Institute to help you gain insight without spending hours and hours reading. In this week's episode we cover quotes from "Worship Matters" by Bob Kauflin, "Spiritual Discipleship" by J. Oswald Sanders, "Spirit of the Disciplines" by Dallas Willard, "You Are What You Love" by James K. A. Smith, and a bonus quote from Martin Luther. 

Quotes include:
"It's in the worship of the Triune God that we are restored by being restoried" - James K. A. Smith
"If you want to experience the flow of love as never before, the next time you are in a competitive situation, pray that the others around you will be more outstanding, more praised, and more used of God than yourself. Really pull for them and rejoice for their successes. If Christians were universally to do this for each other, the Earth would soon be filled with the knowledge of God's glory." - Dallas Willard
"It's inconsistent to profess that we love God while withholding love from those he came to serve." - Bob Kauflin
"We are all beggars living on the bounty of God." - Martin Luther
"The disciple's love for Christ is to be supreme over self-love." - J. Oswald Sanders
